questionList.questionText: A 56-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up.  Six months ago, the patient was diagnosed with major depressive disorder during an evaluation for low energy, poor sleep, weight gain, and difficulty concentrating at work.  She was initially treated with escitalopram, but her depressive symptoms were only slightly improved after 2 months of treatment.  Her medication was switched to venlafaxine, which was subsequently titrated to maximal therapeutic dosage over the course of 3 months.  The patient reports that her depression has improved with treatment, although she still has occasional insomnia.  Her energy has increased back to baseline level; she now feels motivated to exercise and has lost 5 pounds.  The patient has no other medical conditions and takes no other medications.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Which of the following should be monitored at this visit?
questionList.explanationText:
Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) (eg, venlafaxine, duloxetine) are frequently prescribed as next step treatment after an adequate trial of a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) (eg, escitalopram) fails.  Many SNRIs, including venlafaxine, are associated with dose-dependent increases in diastolic and systolic blood pressure.  Blood pressure should be assessed before starting an SNRI and regularly monitored throughout treatment.

As a class, SNRIs inhibit the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine.  Venlafaxine has the unique property of possessing significantly higher affinity for the serotonin transporter relative to the norepinephrine transporter, which results in venlafaxine behaving like an SSRI at lower doses and demonstrating significant norepinephrine reuptake inhibition at higher doses.  Because this noradrenergic drive is what leads to hypertension, the risk with venlafaxine is most pronounced at doses ≥225 mg.  If sustained increases in blood pressure are noted, options include dose reduction or switching to an alternate antidepressant.

(Choice A)  Plasma levels of SNRIs are not routinely monitored and would not be indicated in a patient experiencing a positive response.  Levels can be used to assess adherence or to identify rapid metabolizers in poor responders.

(Choice C)  Complete blood counts are not routinely monitored during venlafaxine treatment.  SNRIs have been associated with a small increased risk of bleeding due to impaired platelet aggregation, but this is mainly a concern in patients who are already taking anticoagulants.  Monitoring for agranulocytosis is required in patients taking clozapine (eg, for schizophrenia).

(Choice D)  Regular monitoring of lipids is not required in patients taking venlafaxine.  Lipids should be routinely monitored in those taking antipsychotics.

(Choice E)  Venlafaxine is not associated with adverse thyroid effects, and monitoring thyroid function tests during treatment is unnecessary.  This patient's initial weight gain was most likely a symptom of her depression (ie, atypical depression frequently presents with increased appetite), and her subsequent weight loss is most likely due to her improvement.

Educational objective:
The serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor venlafaxine is associated with dose-dependent hypertension due to increased norepinephrine reuptake inhibition at higher dose ranges.  Blood pressure should be assessed before starting venlafaxine and regularly monitored throughout treatment.

questionList.title: Depression

Accelerated hypertension after venlafaxine usage.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, comes to the office for a 6-week postpartum checkup following an induction of labor and vaginal delivery at 38 weeks gestation for preeclampsia with severe features.  Her pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated, and the patient has no chronic medical conditions.  She is currently breastfeeding and supplementing with pumped breast milk.  The patient has not resumed her menses and is taking a progestin-only pill for contraception.  The patient says, "The baby is healthy, which is great, but I haven't been sleeping much and have been very tired.  My mom is coming to stay with us, so I'm hoping to get some rest soon."  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 68/min.  BMI is 24 kg/m2.  Breast and pelvic examinations are normal.  Which of the following should be performed at this visit?
questionList.explanationText:
Postpartum blues, depression & psychosis

Postpartum blues

Postpartum depression

Postpartum psychosis

Prevalence

  • 40%-80%
  • 8%-15%
  • 0.1%-0.2%

Onset

  • 2-3 days (resolves within 14 days)
  • Typically within 4-6 weeks (can be up to 1 year)
  • Days to weeks

Symptoms

  • Mild depression, tearfulness, irritability
  • ≥2 weeks of moderate to severe depression, sleep or appetite disturbance, low energy, psychomotor changes, guilt, concentration difficulty, suicidal ideation
  • Delusions, hallucinations, thought disorganization, bizarre behavior

Postpartum depression (also known as depression with postpartum onset) is common, affecting up to 15% of mothers, and typically develops within 4-6 weeks after delivery.  It poses a significant risk to both maternal and infant well-being because women with postpartum depression can have difficulty with infant bonding and breastfeeding and are at risk for suicide and infanticide.

Patients sometimes do not recognize the symptoms of postpartum depression because they often overlap with a normal postpartum course, as evidenced by the fatigue and sleep disturbance experienced by this patient.  In addition, women may underreport symptoms due to fear of stigmatization and preconceived maternal roles (eg, immediate bonding).

Because of the high incidence of postpartum depression and underreporting of symptoms, all women require screening (regardless of prior psychiatric history) with a standardized, validated tool such as the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS).  The EPDS has a high sensitivity (90%); women with a positive screen for postpartum depression require further evaluation, treatment, and close follow-up.

(Choice A)  A 24-hour urine protein collection is used to diagnose preeclampsia.  Although this patient had preeclampsia with severe features during her pregnancy, most cases of preeclampsia resolve after delivery—as is likely in this patient with a normal postpartum blood pressure.

(Choice C)  Postpartum glucose tolerance testing is performed in patients who had gestational diabetes mellitus to evaluate for overt type 2 diabetes mellitus postpartum.

(Choice D)  If this patient's depression screening is positive, she may require evaluation for medical causes of depression, such as hypothyroidism (eg, thyroid function tests).

(Choice E)  A transvaginal ultrasound can be performed postpartum if there is concern for retained placenta (eg, persistent vaginal bleeding, malodorous lochia) or a new pregnancy.  Not resuming menses at 6 weeks postpartum is common in breastfeeding women; pregnancy is unlikely in this patient who has lactational amenorrhea and is also using contraception.

Educational objective:
Postpartum depression has a high incidence and is often underreported.  Therefore, all women (regardless of prior psychiatric history) require screening for postpartum depression (eg, Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale).
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Peripartum depression

questionList.questionText: A 17-year-old girl comes to the office for a routine maintenance evaluation.  The patient is thinking about having sex for the first time.  She has been in a relationship for 6 months and would like to have a "physical connection" with her boyfriend.  The patient has not felt pressured by him and feels comfortable and safe in the relationship.  She has fantasies often about having sex with her boyfriend and masturbates 4 or 5 times a week.  The patient has no history of partnered sexual activity.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician at this time?
questionList.explanationText:
Medical aspects of sexual health (eg, contraceptive options, STI prevention) should be addressed at all routine health care visits for adolescents.  However, physicians may also be adolescents' only trusted source of information about sexuality and are in a unique position to help adolescents feel comfortable asking any questions they may have.  Keys to promoting open discussion include providing a private setting, assuring confidentiality, normalizing discussions of sex, removing stigma and discomfort by being nonjudgmental, and avoiding assumptions by using open-ended and gender-neutral questions about identity and sexual behaviors.

This patient has been forthcoming about her thoughts of becoming sexually active with her boyfriend.  The best response is to convey that it is normal to have questions and begin an open-ended discussion of any concerns that she may have.  This should precede the physician's redirection of the conversation to specific counseling regarding contraceptive options and STI prevention, which may inadvertently discourage the patient from bringing up her own questions and concerns (Choices A and C).

(Choice B)  Confidentiality should be emphasized when discussing sexual issues, especially with adolescents.  It is premature to encourage this patient to share her plans with her parents without first exploring her concerns or understanding her relationship with her parents.

(Choice D)  This response could make the patient feel defensive about her plans to have sex, which may preclude an open discussion about healthy and safe sexual practices.

Educational objective:
Physicians are in a unique position to answer adolescents' questions about sexuality.  Keys to promoting open discussion include providing a private setting, assuring confidentiality, normalizing discussions of sex, removing stigma and discomfort by being nonjudgmental, and avoiding assumptions by using open-ended and gender-neutral questions.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Child and adolescent mental health

answerChoiceList.choice: "Deciding when to have sex is up to you, but we should talk about ways to protect yourself from sexually transmitted infections."
"Having sex for the first time is a big decision; have you thought about discussing it with your parents?"
"It sounds like you may decide to have sex with your boyfriend soon; have you thought about how to prevent an unintended pregnancy?"
"It's normal for teenagers to experiment with sexual activities; but do you think you're ready to have sex?"
"Wondering about when to have sex is very normal; what questions do you have about sex and your body?"

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Physicians talking about sex, sexuality, and protection with adolescents.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old man is brought to the office by his wife due to her concerns that "he is not himself."  The patient has been very irritable and hyperactive with difficulty sleeping since returning from a family funeral a week ago.  His wife reports that he has been very distracted and unproductive at the factory where he works, to the point that his employer has placed him on probation.  Two days ago, he nearly sustained a serious injury while performing risky maneuvers with heavy machinery.  When asked about his job, the patient says he has had no difficulties and describes his idea to "use special robot prosthetics to make the production line faster than ever and double everyone's productivity."  The patient adds, "I don't know what my wife is worried about.  If this job doesn't work out, I'll start my own company."  His wife reports that he behaved similarly about 2 years ago and embarrassed her at a party by talking incessantly about his idea for a robotic invention.  The patient has no history of depression.  He drinks 2 or 3 beers on weekends and has been smoking marijuana approximately once a month for the past year.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min.  Urine toxicology screen is positive for tetrahydrocannabinol.  Except for marked restlessness and fidgeting, physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's behavior?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's 1-week history of irritable mood, hyperactivity, distractibility, impulsivity, decreased sleep, and grandiosity resulting in severe impairment (risky behavior at work resulting in probation and a near serious injury) suggest a manic episode.  The presence of a manic episode makes bipolar I disorder the most likely diagnosis.

The diagnosis of hypomanic and manic episodes requires elevated/irritable mood and increased energy, plus 3 of the following (or 4 if mood is irritable):

  • D - Distractibility
  • I - Impulsivity (high-risk behaviors [eg, spending, sexual])
  • G - Grandiosity
  • F - Flight of ideas/racing thoughts
  • A - Activity (increased goal-directed activity/psychomotor agitation)
  • S - Sleep (decreased need)
  • T - Talkativeness/pressured speech

In hypomania, symptoms are less severe and functioning is improved or only slightly impaired, unlike in this patient who is on probation and whose risky behavior could have resulted in serious injury.  If psychotic symptoms are present, the episode is manic by definition.  Diagnosis of bipolar I disorder does not require a history of major depressive episodes.  Bipolar II disorder is characterized by episodes of major depression and hypomania (not mania, as in this patient) (Choice C).

(Choice A)  Some symptoms of mania overlap with those of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) (eg, hyperactivity, distractibility, impulsivity).  However, ADHD symptoms are chronic, not episodic.

(Choice D)  Cyclothymic disorder involves 2 years of fluctuating periods with mild depressive symptoms as well as symptoms of hypomania that never meet the full criteria for hypomanic, manic, or major depressive episodes.

(Choice E)  The diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires a depressive or manic episode co-occurring with symptoms of schizophrenia and a lifetime history of ≥2 weeks of psychotic symptoms in the absence of mood episodes.

(Choice F)  Although this patient's urine toxicology screen is positive for tetrahydrocannabinol (eg, marijuana), he has a history suggestive of a mood episode prior to his use of marijuana, which started within the past year.  In addition, although cannabis intoxication can present with euphoria, anxiety, or psychosis, it is more likely to cause psychomotor slowing rather than hyperactivity.  Intoxication with stimulants or cocaine is more likely to induce manic symptoms.

Educational objective:
Bipolar I disorder includes manic episode(s) with or without a history of major depressive episodes.  Bipolar II is distinguished from bipolar I by hypomanic episodes (less severe, less functional impairment, no psychotic symptoms) and a history of ≥1 depressive episodes.

questionList.title: Bipolar disorder

questionList.questionText: A 61-year-old woman comes to the office accompanied by her daughter due to headaches.  The headaches occur 2 or 3 times a week and feel like "a band around my head that someone is constantly tightening."  The patient also reports excessive tiredness, restless sleep, and decreased appetite, attributing these symptoms to aging.  She has no visual disturbances, dizziness, vomiting, weakness, or other neurologic symptoms.  The patient experienced similar headaches a few years ago; after they restarted 2 months ago, she was persuaded by her daughter to get evaluated.  The daughter mentions that her mother moved in with her a few months ago due to recent unemployment and financial concerns.  Since moving, the patient has not been going out with friends and says, "I get anxious driving from my daughter's house because I don't know the roads."  She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 2 years ago; hemoglobin A1c was 5.8% 2 months ago.  Medications include metformin and ibuprofen as needed.  Medical history is otherwise noncontributory.  Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's classic description of tension-type headaches, normal examination, and other symptoms suggestive of depression (eg, poor sleep, loss of appetite, fatigue, anxiety), may indicate an underlying psychiatric disorder.  Patients with depression or anxiety often come to the office with headaches or other physical symptoms (eg, fatigue, insomnia, nonspecific aches and pains) due to a lack of psychologic awareness or a perceived stigma around mental health issues.

In the absence of new physical findings in a medically stable patient, the most appropriate next step is to screen the patient for depression by specifically inquiring about depressive symptoms (eg, depressed mood, anhedonia).  For patients who may be unaware of or reluctant to admit to feeling depressed, asking if they are able to enjoy their usual activities is helpful.

(Choice A)  Obtaining further collateral information from the daughter may be useful but should not take precedence over obtaining a thorough history from the patient.

(Choice C)  Neuroimaging would not be helpful because this patient describes typical tension-type headaches similar to those she had a few years ago.  In addition, her neurologic examination is normal.

(Choice D)  This patient has stable glycemic control as demonstrated by the normal hemoglobin A1c level taken 2 months ago; a repeat hemoglobin A1c level is not indicated at this time.

(Choice E)  Although reassurance regarding the benign nature of the headaches and regular follow-up is indicated, assessment for depression is a priority given the other symptoms suggestive of this condition.

(Choice F)  Although relaxation techniques and biofeedback can be considered in the management of tension-type headaches, it would be premature to recommend this intervention prior to evaluating for depression.

(Choice G)  Although giant cell arteritis (evaluated by temporal artery biopsy) can cause headache and fatigue, it is typically characterized by new headaches, abrupt onset of visual disturbances, jaw claudication, and constitutional symptoms such as fever.  This patient's headaches are suggestive of recurrent tension-type headaches.

Educational objective:
Patients with underlying mood disorders frequently come to the office with physical rather than psychologic symptoms.  Evaluation should include screening for depression by inquiring about mood and ability to enjoy usual activities.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Depression

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask permission to speak with the daughter alone
Inquire about the patient's ability to enjoy usual activities
Obtain a CT scan of the brain
Provide reassurance and schedule regular follow-up

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old man with bipolar I disorder comes to the office for a follow-up visit.  He experienced his first manic episode 7 years ago, and the disorder responded well to lithium.  The patient became nonadherent with his medication after his condition improved and then experienced a second manic episode 9 months later.  Over the next 5 years, he experienced 3 additional manic episodes, 2 depressive episodes, and a suicide attempt.  Since his most recent hospitalization for a manic episode 3 years ago, he has remained on lithium and has had no depressive, manic, or hypomanic signs or symptoms.  The patient also has no lithium adverse effects, and levels confirm that he is taking the medication as prescribed.  Today, he inquires about the possibility of discontinuing lithium, adding that he does not want to be dependent on medication and is "in a much more stable place than before."  Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Bipolar I disorder is a mood disorder characterized by ≥1 episodes of mania; it also often includes major depressive episodes.  Patients with severe bipolar I disorder (eg, frequent relapses, suicide attempts, recurrent hospitalizations) require lifelong maintenance pharmacotherapy to reduce the risk for relapse.

Patients often struggle with the idea of taking medication for life and may want to discontinue maintenance pharmacotherapy for a variety of reasons (eg, adverse effects, desire to be "medication free," poor illness awareness).  However, in most bipolar patients, discontinuing maintenance treatment leads to a recurrent mood episode within a year.  This patient's request to stop medication despite his history of 7 prior mood episodes, a suicide attempt, and a previous failed discontinuation attempt should cause alarm.  In addition, lithium's protective effects against suicide would be lost.

In patients with limited insight into the dangers of stopping treatment, respect for patient autonomy must be balanced by the physician's responsibility to act in the best interest of the patient.  Nonjudgmental education about realistic concerns for life-damaging consequences (eg, bankruptcy, incarceration, divorce), suicide, and future treatment resistance should be reinforced.  With this patient, ongoing discussion over multiple sessions, rather than an immediate decision, is recommended.  This allows further understanding of and working through this patient's fear of being "dependent" on medication and avoids an impulsive decision.

(Choices B and D)  Stopping medication altogether and/or pursuing psychotherapy alone places the patient at unnecessary risk for a recurrent mood episode.  Although psychotherapy may be an important part of treatment, in patients with bipolar I disorder, it should be combined with medication management.

(Choice C)  This patient's bipolar I disorder is stable, and he is tolerating lithium without adverse effects; therefore, switching to an alternate treatment (eg, valproate, quetiapine) is not indicated.  Furthermore, discontinuing lithium quickly poses a high risk for relapse and even suicide.  The immediate focus should be on providing nonjudgmental education about the significant risks for medication nonadherence while encouraging a discussion over time.

(Choice E)  Given the relapse risk, an additional year of treatment followed by gradual discontinuation is contraindicated in this patient with severe bipolar I disorder.  Indefinite maintenance therapy should be recommended.

Educational objective:
Bipolar I disorder is a highly recurrent illness requiring long-term maintenance pharmacotherapy to decrease the risk for relapse.  Patients asking to stop maintenance treatment should be nonjudgmentally educated about the dangers of nonadherence.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bipolar disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Discontinue lithium and recommend initiating psychotherapy
Discontinue lithium gradually over the course of 2-4 weeks and initiate valproate
Discontinue lithium gradually over the course of several months
Recommend that the patient continue lithium for an additional year then discontinue gradually

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Evidence-based guidelines for treating bipolar disorder: revised third edition recommendations from the British Association for Psychopharmacology.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old woman comes to the office due to insomnia.  She had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery 3 weeks ago and is on maternity leave to care for her daughter.  The patient awakens regularly at 4:00 AM although the infant is sleeping.  During the day, she has little energy and forces herself to shower and care for the infant.  The patient shares that her husband returned to work 2 weeks after the infant was born, and although she feels he tries to be supportive, she finds herself feeling annoyed with him at times.  She is breastfeeding and supplementing with formula as needed.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  The patient says, "I know it's pretty normal to feel this way with a newborn.  I'm sure I'd feel better if I could just get some rest."  Which of the following is the most appropriate physician statement?
questionList.explanationText:
Postpartum blues, depression & psychosis

Postpartum blues

Postpartum depression

Postpartum psychosis

Prevalence

  • 40%-80%
  • 8%-15%
  • 0.1%-0.2%

Onset

  • 2-3 days (resolves within 14 days)
  • Typically within 4-6 weeks (can be up to 1 year)
  • Days to weeks

Symptoms

  • Mild depression, tearfulness, irritability
  • ≥2 weeks of moderate to severe depression, sleep or appetite disturbance, low energy, psychomotor changes, guilt, concentration difficulty, suicidal ideation
  • Delusions, hallucinations, thought disorganization, bizarre behavior

Although interrupted sleep is common in new mothers, several features of this patient's presentation are concerning for postpartum depression (ie, major depressive disorder with peripartum onset), including:

  • marked sleep disturbance with early-morning awakening
  • low energy
  • amotivation (eg, forces herself to shower and care for the infant)

leading to impaired functioning.

Postpartum depression is common and, if left untreated, can result in impaired maternal-infant bonding and negative impact on both maternal and infant health.  Therefore, all women with mood symptoms after birth should be further screened for postpartum depression.  In this situation, asking about hopelessness in a patient who struggles to identify depression (eg, "I know it's pretty normal," "I'd feel better if I could just get some rest") provides the physician with another way of determining the presence of depressed mood (eg, sad, hopeless, empty).

If positive for postpartum depression, then appropriate treatment should include pharmacologic and therapeutic interventions (Choice A).  In addition, patients who confirm hopelessness along with other symptoms of postpartum depression should be screened for the presence of imminent risk (eg, suicidal ideation).  If a patient is actively suicidal or has thoughts of harming the infant, hospitalization should be pursued.

(Choice B)  Postpartum blues is a self-limited condition with milder depressive symptoms that typically peak at 5 days postpartum and resolve within 2 weeks.  However, this patient delivered 3 weeks ago, and her symptoms are more severe (eg, terminal insomnia, low energy, amotivation, impaired functioning), which requires further screening for postpartum depression and potentially treatment beyond "some coping strategies that may be helpful."

(Choices C and D)  Maximizing restful sleep by obtaining additional childcare support and/or considering safe sleep medication options might be helpful for new mothers managing postpartum blues; however, assessing the patient for postpartum depression takes precedence because she would require more intensive treatment if positive.

Educational objective:
If left untreated, postpartum depression (ie, major depressive disorder with peripartum onset) can result in impaired maternal-infant bonding and increased risk for suicide and/or harm to the infant.  New mothers with mood changes should be further assessed for postpartum depression.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Depression

answerChoiceList.choice: "Experiencing postpartum sleep and mood changes is common; would you be interested in talking to a counselor about how you've been feeling?"
"It's common to have these symptoms for 1-2 weeks at the start of the postpartum period; let's talk about some coping strategies that may be helpful."
"It's hard to rest and relax after you have a baby; what are your thoughts on finding an additional support person to help with childcare?"
"Sleep is very important during the postpartum period; let's try a medication that's safe while breastfeeding so that you can get some rest."
"Taking care of a baby is exhausting, and it can be difficult to find time for yourself; have you been experiencing any feelings of hopelessness?"

questionList.questionText: A 60-year-old woman with a history of locally advanced breast cancer comes to the office for scheduled follow-up.  The patient underwent a lumpectomy followed by radiation therapy and completion of chemotherapy 6 months ago.  She is currently taking an aromatase inhibitor.  The patient feels that the fatigue she experienced during her chemotherapy has not improved.  She has been sleeping poorly and recently left her volunteer job at the library because she is "too distracted to sit and alphabetize books."  The patient had previously been meeting weekly with friends for lunch but has not replied to recent invitations.  Since her last appointment 3 months ago, she has lost 3 kg (6.6 lb); otherwise, vital signs are within normal limits, there are no changes on physical examination, and laboratory and imaging studies are unremarkable.  When informed of these normal results, she says, "That's good to hear, but I'm anxious that the cancer is coming back.  Why else would I feel so tired all the time?"  Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Although fatigue may persist after completion of chemotherapy, and anxiety about cancer recurrence is normal, this patient is showing other signs and symptoms that are concerning for major depressive disorder (MDD).  She has loss of interest (eg, no longer meeting her friends for lunch), impaired concentration (eg, too distracted to alphabetize books), sleep disturbance, weight loss, and social isolation (eg, not responding to invitations) lasting >2 weeks, strongly suggestive of MDD.  This should prompt assessment of other depressive symptoms (eg, feelings of worthlessness/guilt, loss of self-esteem, suicidal ideation).

Recognition of major depression in medically ill patients is important because untreated depression can have a major impact on quality of life and can negatively affect treatment adherence and medical outcome.  Physicians should not assume that depression is a normal reaction to a cancer diagnosis or that impairment in sleep, appetite, and energy level are due to the cancer or its treatment.  Patients with cancer can be safely and effectively treated with psychotherapy and/or antidepressant medications.

(Choice A)  Although some of the patient's symptoms (eg, fatigue, cognitive problems) could be caused by an aromatase inhibitor, her anhedonia, poor sleep, and weight loss raise concern for MDD.  Musculoskeletal symptoms (eg, arthralgia, joint stiffness, bone pain) and sexual dysfunction are the most common side effects of aromatase inhibitors.

(Choice B)  Depressive disorder due to another medical condition is only diagnosed when there is evidence that the mood disturbance is the direct result of another medical condition (eg, hypothyroidism, Parkinson disease).  In the absence of any findings on physical examination or laboratory and imaging studies, this patient's depression is unlikely due to breast cancer recurrence or another undiagnosed medical condition.

(Choice C)  Illness anxiety disorder involves excessive fears of having a serious illness.  It would not explain this patient's depressive symptoms, and her fear of breast cancer recurring is normal.

(Choice E) This patient's symptoms are more severe than would be seen in a normal reaction and are causing significant distress and functional impairment.  Further assessment and treatment are indicated.

Educational objective:
Diagnosing major depressive disorder in patients with cancer is difficult because somatic symptoms of depression (eg, fatigue, weight loss) may overlap with those of cancer and its treatment.  If these symptoms are associated with depressed mood or loss of interest, major depressive disorder should be considered.

questionList.title: Depression

answerChoiceList.choice: Depressive disorder due to another medical condition
Normal reaction to cancer diagnosis and treatment

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 30 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: suicide attempt
History of Present Illness:
• brought in by ambulance
• patient's boyfriend found her sleeping next to a bottle of alprazolam; he had received a text from her that read: "I'm not good enough for anyone.  Goodbye."
• patient reports taking 3 of the 1-mg tablets "with the hope of not waking up"
• boyfriend states she has been listless and sleeping until noon every day since he mentioned wanting to end their 4-year relationship 3 weeks ago
Past Medical History:
• depression "on and off" throughout her life; no prior suicide attempts
• boyfriend states, "She can be unusually upbeat and confident for days to weeks, and when she's like that she gets to work early in the morning, works until closing, and goes out for drinks and dancing until 2 in the morning."
Medications:
• none
Allergies:
• no known drug allergies
Family History:
• noncontributory
Psychosocial History:
• retail worker
• drinks 3 or 4 glasses of wine a week; no other recreational substance use

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
37 C
(98.6 F)		70/min14/min118/70
mm Hg		–––20 kg/m2

• Appearance: tearful; wearing oversized t-shirt and sweatpants; unkempt hair
• Pulmonary: clear lungs
• Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; normal S1 and S2
• Abdominal: normal bowel sounds; soft and nontender
• Neurologic: alert and fully oriented; normal muscle tone; steady gait
• Mental status: mood is "depressed"; affect is constricted and minimally reactive; patient moves and speaks slowly; no suicidal ideation; she states, "I'm glad my boyfriend found me."

Diagnostic Studies
• none

Question: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Bipolar & related disorders

Manic episode

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features (makes episode manic by definition)

Hypomanic episode

  • Symptoms less severe
  • ≥4 consecutive days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

Bipolar I

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common but not required for diagnosis

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • ≥1 major depressive episodes

Cyclothymic disorder

  • ≥2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for hypomanic or major depressive episodes

This patient's current 3-week episode of depression and history suggestive of hypomanic episodes are most consistent with a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder.  Her current depressive symptoms include depressed mood, suicidal ideation and attempt, loss of motivation/interest, hypersomnia, feeling of worthlessness, and psychomotor retardation.  Evidence of past hypomanic episodes includes distinct periods lasting ≥4 days of elevated mood, increased energy and goal-directed activity, increased self-confidence, and decreased need for sleep.

Patients with bipolar II disorder do not experience full-blown manic episodes (ie, severe symptoms with marked functional impairment), making the differential diagnosis from other psychiatric disorders more difficult.  Whereas patients in a manic episode frequently require inpatient treatment and may be psychotic, patients with hypomania are typically able to continue working.

(Choice A)  Although this patient's depression was precipitated by a stressor, adjustment disorder with depressed mood is not diagnosed when symptoms meet the diagnostic criteria for another mental disorder.

(Choice C)  The depressive and hypomanic episodes in bipolar II disorder may resemble the mood instability seen in borderline personality disorder.  However, the labile mood states in borderline personality disorder are brief, typically lasting hours to days (rather than weeks to months).  There is insufficient evidence to diagnose borderline personality disorder in this patient; she does not exhibit a lifelong pattern of identity disturbance, feelings of emptiness, intense anger, splitting, or self-mutilating behavior.

(Choices D and E)  Major depressive disorder and persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) are unipolar disorders; these patients do not have hypomanic or manic episodes.  Persistent depressive disorder is characterized by chronic depressive symptoms lasting ≥2 years.

Educational objective:
Bipolar II disorder is characterized by distinct episodes of major depression and hypomania.  In contrast, the labile mood states seen in borderline personality disorder tend to fluctuate more rapidly.

questionList.questionText: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the office by her husband.  He says that over the past 2 months, the patient has become increasingly depressed to the point that she rarely gets out of bed.  She has called in sick to work, does not answer the phone when her friends call, and has lost 4.5 kg (10 lb).  The patient has a history of 2 psychiatric hospitalizations.  She was first hospitalized at age 27 for a period of extreme irritability and agitation that lasted a week.  At that time, she spoke so rapidly that she was difficult to understand and stayed up for nights dictating letters to government officials about her solution to world hunger.  Last year, the patient was hospitalized for severe depression and a suicide attempt.  She responded within days to venlafaxine but discontinued the medication shortly after discharge because she "felt fine."  On mental status examination, the patient shows a depressed and tearful affect.  She admits to "hearing the devil saying I'm a useless waste of time."  Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for the long-term treatment of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is currently experiencing symptoms of depression with psychotic features.  Her history of mania, suggested by an episode of increased irritability, agitation, pressured speech, decreased need for sleep, and grandiosity, makes bipolar I disorder the most likely diagnosis.

Common options for maintenance treatment of bipolar disorder include lithium and valproate.  The second-generation antipsychotic quetiapine and the anticonvulsant lamotrigine have also demonstrated efficacy.  Lithium would be particularly helpful in this patient because it would reduce the risk of suicide.

(Choice A)  Clozapine is reserved for use in treatment-resistant schizophrenia due to the potential for life-threatening agranulocytosis.

(Choices B, E, and F)  Antidepressant monotherapy should be avoided in patients with bipolar I disorder due to the risk of mood destabilization.  Fluoxetine, mirtazapine, and venlafaxine would be appropriate maintenance treatments for patients with recurrent, unipolar major depressive disorder but would risk inducing mania in this patient with bipolar I disorder.  Her uncharacteristically rapid response to venlafaxine within a few days (typical time to response is 2-4 weeks) is another clue that she has bipolar disorder.

(Choice C)  Although haloperidol has a role in treating acute mania, particularly with psychotic features, it is not used for long-term management due to its side effect profile.

Educational objective:
Lithium, valproate, quetiapine, and lamotrigine are first-line maintenance treatments for bipolar disorder.

Recent advances in the understanding and management of bipolar disorder in adults.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to poor sleep and feeling "worthless."  His insomnia and poor self-esteem began 2 months ago when he discovered that his girlfriend was romantically involved with one of her co-workers.  The patient was very disappointed by this news as he thought he and his girlfriend were close and had a good sexual relationship.  He immediately ended the relationship and has since stopped socializing, preferring instead to stay home alone.  He admits to having little interest in dating women now, even when they seem to be a good match.  Although the patient continues to meet his deadlines and fulfill all his professional responsibilities, he feels less motivated at work.  He continues to go to the gym regularly, as exercising helps him "escape from feelings" he still has for his former girlfriend.  He reluctantly admits to occasionally using marijuana to help him sleep.  The patient has no psychiatric history.  There is a family history of depression in his older sister, who was successfully treated with venlafaxine.  Which of the following treatments is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Differential diagnosis of depressed mood

Major depressive disorder

  • ≥2 weeks
  • ≥5 of 9 symptoms: depressed mood & SIGECAPS
  • Significant functional impairment
  • No lifetime history of mania

Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia)

  • Chronic depressed mood ≥2 years
  • ≥2 of the following: appetite disturbance, sleep disturbance, low energy, low self-esteem, poor concentration, hopelessness

Adjustment disorder with depressed mood

  • Onset within 3 months of identifiable stressor
  • Marked distress &/or functional impairment
  • Does not meet criteria for another DSM-5-TR disorder

Normal stress response

  • Not excessive or out of proportion to severity of stressor
  • No significant functional impairment

SIGECAPS = Sleep disturbance, loss of Interest, excessive Guilt, low Energy, impaired Concentration, Appetite disturbance, Psychomotor agitation/retardation, and Suicidal ideation. 

This patient's development of sleep disturbance, low self-esteem, and social isolation in response to the stress of a romantic breakup is consistent with an adjustment disorder.  Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and rarely last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.  Diagnosis requires evidence of significant distress or impairment, as seen in this patient's seeking help for his symptoms and social impairment.  He lacks sufficient symptoms to meet the criteria for major depressive disorder as he does not have evidence of impaired concentration, low energy, appetite disturbance, psychomotor agitation or retardation, or suicidal ideation; therefore, the diagnosis of adjustment disorder is appropriate.

The treatment of choice for adjustment disorder is psychotherapy, which focuses on developing coping mechanisms and improving the individual's response to and attitude about the stressful situation.  Helping this patient cope with his feelings of disappointment, improve his self-esteem, and eventually become open to new relationships would be appropriate.

(Choices A, B, C, and E)  The antidepressants bupropion, fluoxetine, mirtazapine, and venlafaxine would all be first-line pharmacologic treatment options if the patient met the criteria for major depressive disorder.  Bupropion has the advantage of not causing sexual side effects but can be activating and worsen insomnia.  If the patient develops major depression, the serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor venlafaxine could be considered given the history of a positive response in a first-degree relative.

(Choice F)  Zolpidem is a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic used to treat insomnia.  Targeting this patient's sleep disturbance alone would not adequately address his adjustment disorder.

Educational objective:
Adjustment disorder involves symptoms causing marked distress and impairment that develop within 3 months in response to a stressor.  It is not diagnosed if symptoms meet the criteria for another specific disorder (eg, major depressive disorder).  The treatment of choice is psychotherapy that focuses on improving coping skills and promoting a return to functioning.

questionList.title: Adjustment disorders

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Adjustment disorder: epidemiology, diagnosis and treatment.

questionList.questionText: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by the police after she was found trespassing at an animal shelter.  The patient had keys to a rental van, as well as numerous collars and leashes.  She says, "The shelter is going to sell the animals to labs, where they'll do horrible experiments on them.  I'm the only one who can save them!"  The patient quit her retail job a week ago to spend more time researching escape routes for the animals.  Throughout the evaluation, she interrupts the physician to yell at other patients and hospital staff walking by the room.  She repeatedly refers to herself as a "cat burglar" and then laughs loudly for a few minutes.  Physical examination is unremarkable and urine drug screening is negative.  Which of the following additional features is most likely in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Manic episode

Clinical
features

  • ≥1 week of elevated or irritable mood & increased energy/activity
  • ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if mood is irritable only) (DIGFAST mnemonic):
    • Distractibility
    • Impulsivity/indiscretion, risky behavior
    • Grandiosity
    • Flight of ideas/racing thoughts
    • Increased activity/psychomotor agitation
    • Decreased need for sleep
    • Talkativeness/pressured speech

Severity

  • Impaired psychosocial function
  • May have psychotic features (hallucinations, delusions)
  • May require hospitalization

This patient's recent history of abnormal mood, impulsive, risky behavior, and grandiosity (ie, belief that only she can save the animals), as well as findings of loud speech, distractibility, and inappropriate joking and laughter on mental status examination, are characteristic of a manic episode of bipolar I disorder.  Patients with mania are often expansive and disinhibited, interacting with strangers without regard to social conventions (eg, yelling at others walking by).  Impaired judgment is common, as with this patient abruptly quitting her job and trespassing at the animal shelter.

A key feature of mania is decreased need for sleep due to increased energy.  This is differentiated from insomnia, which refers to difficulty sleeping despite feeling tired.  Patients in a manic episode may sleep only a few hours or go without sleep entirely for several days.  Despite lack of sleep, they feel well rested and energetic.  Mania typically has an acute onset with rapid progression over a few days, resulting in marked impairment in functioning.  Hospitalization may be necessary to protect the patient from further destructive behaviors.

(Choice A)  Although psychotic features (eg, delusions, hallucinations) may develop during a manic episode, tactile hallucinations (eg, bugs crawling on the skin) are uncommon.  Tactile hallucinations are most commonly associated with substance use disorders or medical conditions.

(Choice B)  Having intrusive, unwanted thoughts is a core feature of obsessive-compulsive disorder.  Although this patient is intensely preoccupied with saving animals, her thoughts are not experienced as intrusive or disturbing, and her behavior is consistent with the increased activity commonly seen in mania.

(Choice C)  A feeling of detachment is a dissociative symptom more commonly seen in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder.

(Choices E and F)  Neglecting personal grooming and increased latency of response are examples of negative symptoms, which are a characteristic feature of schizophrenia, not bipolar disorder.

Educational objective:
Core features of a manic episode include elevated or irritable mood, increased energy/activity, and a decreased need for sleep.  Manic patients may feel rested and energetic despite getting very little or no sleep.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bipolar disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Experiencing a sensation of bugs crawling on skin
Feeling a sense of detachment from self and the environment
Feeling well rested despite minimal sleep
Pausing for long periods prior to responding to questions

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Mania.
The diagnosis and management of bipolar I and II disorders: clinical practice update.

questionList.questionText: A 52-year-old man with a history of schizoaffective disorder is admitted to the hospital for treatment of a lower extremity cellulitis.  The patient does not appear to have any other acute medical illness.  He is continued on his home medications—lithium, risperidone, and sertraline—and cephalosporin therapy is initiated to treat his infection.  During the hospital stay, the patient also receives ibuprofen and acetaminophen for pain and lorazepam as needed for anxiety and insomnia.  His infection improves over the next 10-14 days, but prior to discharge, he develops repeated episodes of vomiting and diarrhea.  At the same time, the patient becomes tremulous and uncoordinated, which makes it difficult for him to walk without falling.  In addition, he seems confused.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination shows fasciculations and bilateral tremor.  Which of the following medications is most likely to have caused this patient's new symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Lithium toxicity

Etiology

Acute toxicity

  • Intentional overdose

Chronic toxicity

  • Decreased renal perfusion (↓ lithium clearance)
    • Dehydration
    • Thiazide diuretics, NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors

Clinical features

Acute toxicity

  • Gastrointestinal: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Late neurologic sequelae

Chronic toxicity (neurologic)

  • Lethargy, confusion, agitation
  • Ataxia, tremor/fasciculations, seizure

Treatment

  • Intravenous hydration
  • Hemodialysis (severe cases)

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

The new onset of severe gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion, ataxia, and tremor (and other symptoms of neuromuscular irritability) in a patient taking lithium suggests lithium toxicity.  Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder and schizoaffective disorder (bipolar type).  It has a narrow therapeutic index and relies on adequate kidney function for its excretion.  This patient likely developed lithium toxicity due to a drug interaction with ibuprofen.  Concurrent use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (eg, ibuprofen) can cause a decrease in renal clearance of lithium and lead to elevated serum lithium levels and lithium toxicity.  Other drugs that increase lithium levels include thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitors, tetracyclines, and metronidazole.

(Choice A)  Acetaminophen may cause gastrointestinal symptoms and hepatic toxicity.  However, it is not likely to cause adverse neurological effects such as ataxia, fasciculations, or tremor.

(Choice C)  Lorazepam toxicity may cause sedation, confusion, and gait disturbance.  However, it would not lead to fasciculations and bilateral tremor.  Alternatively, lorazepam withdrawal is unlikely to occur after 10-14 days of as-needed use.

(Choice D)  Risperidone, a second-generation antipsychotic, may cause galactorrhea, orthostasis, metabolic syndrome, and extrapyramidal symptoms.  Gastrointestinal symptoms are unlikely.  In rare cases, risperidone can cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome, characterized by autonomic instability, high fevers, delirium, and muscle rigidity.

(Choice E)  Sertraline, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, may cause gastrointestinal symptoms, fasciculations, and tremor.  However, it is unlikely to lead to confusion or ataxia in therapeutic doses.  If combined with other serotonergic drugs, it can lead to serotonin syndrome, which is characterized by mental status changes, autonomic instability, hyperthermia, and neuromuscular irritability.

Educational objective:
The addition of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (or thiazide diuretics, ACE inhibitors, tetracyclines, and metronidazole) to lithium can increase serum lithium levels and lead to symptoms of toxicity, including gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion, ataxia, and tremor.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Lithium

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Drug interactions with lithium: an update.
Drug-related admissions due to interaction with an old drug, lithium.

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 27 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: "I feel hopeless."

History of Present Illness:

  • depressed mood and feeling of worthlessness following breakup with his girlfriend 6 weeks ago
  • feels tired despite sleeping 12 hours a day
  • difficulty completing daily activities like showering and getting dressed
  • unable to concentrate on anything; spends time flipping through television channels to distract himself from feeling sad

Past Medical History:

  • multiple depressive episodes starting at age 17; suicide attempt at age 22; no history of antidepressant trial
  • psychotic episode at age 25, in which the patient believed he was a renowned sea captain; spent savings buying a boat and stayed up for days recruiting others for his expedition; symptoms fully resolved with inpatient treatment; patient did not follow up and discontinued medication shortly after discharge

Medications:

  • none

Allergies:

  • no known drug allergies

Family History:

  • noncontributory

Psychosocial History:

  • plumber
  • drinks 4 or 5 beers a week; no other recreational substance use

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO SatHtWtBMI
37 C
(98.6 F)		88/min15/min114/76
mm Hg		99%
on RA		––21 kg/m2
 
  • Appearance: dressed casually with wrinkled shirt; tearful when discussing breakup
  • Pulmonary: clear lungs
  • Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; normal S1 and S2
  • Abdominal: normal bowel sounds; soft and nontender; no hepatosplenomegaly
  • Neurologic: alert and fully oriented
  • Mental status: slow rate of speech with moderate response latency; patient states, "I can't live without my girlfriend" but has no suicidal thoughts; does not appear to be internally preoccupied

Diagnostic Studies

  • none

Question: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Mood disorders with psychotic features vs primary psychotic disorders

Major depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features

  • Psychotic symptoms occur exclusively during mood episodes

Schizophrenia

  • Mood symptoms, if present, are brief & not prominent

Schizoaffective disorder

  • Major depressive or manic episode occurs concurrently with symptoms of schizophrenia
  • Patient has a lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations for ≥2 weeks outside of mood episode
  • Mood episodes are prominent & recur throughout illness

All patients who have depression should be screened for a history of mania to differentiate unipolar from bipolar disorders.  This patient's current symptoms of a major depressive episode and history of a manic episode are consistent with bipolar I disorder.  His depressive symptoms include depressed mood, feeling of worthlessness, hypersomnia, low energy/lethargy, and psychomotor retardation (ie, slow rate of speech with latency) on mental status examination.  The patient's history of a psychotic episode 2 years ago, characterized by grandiose delusions, decreased need for sleep, and impulsive spending, is characteristic of a manic episode with psychotic features.

Patients with bipolar I disorder may have psychotic symptoms (eg, delusions, hallucinations) when they experience severe manic and depressive episodes.  The absence of psychotic symptoms outside of mood episodes, as in this patient who is psychotic only when he is manic, rules out primary psychotic disorders.

(Choice A)  Although the patient's current depressive episode was triggered by a romantic breakup, adjustment disorder is not diagnosed when symptoms are severe enough to meet criteria for another psychiatric disorder such as bipolar disorder.

(Choice C)  Patients with borderline personality disorder commonly experience mood swings in reaction to interpersonal stressors.  However, a personality disorder would not adequately explain this patient's recurrent manic and depressive episodes, and he lacks key borderline personality features such as unstable identity and repetitive self-harm.

(Choice D)  Major depressive disorder is characterized by major depressive episodes and no history of mania.

(Choice E)  Schizoaffective disorder is a primary psychotic disorder characterized by psychotic symptoms that occur independently of mood episodes.  This patient's psychotic symptoms occurred solely when he was clearly manic and completely resolved with treatment of his manic episode.  Diagnostic criteria for schizoaffective disorder include a history of ≥2 weeks of psychotic symptoms in the absence of a mood episode.

Educational objective:
Bipolar disorder is characterized by depressive and manic episodes.  If psychotic symptoms occur, they are present only in the context of a manic or major depressive episode.

Diagnosis and management of bipolar disorder in primary care: a DSM-5 update.

questionList.questionText: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for assessment of behavioral issues.  His mother explains that he has "not been himself" since starting middle school a few months ago.  The patient has become increasingly argumentative with his parents and becomes irritable with his siblings for no clear reason.  He spends most of his time in his bedroom and comes out only to eat dinner, quickly returning to his room after only a few bites.  He watches TV late into the night due to restlessness, struggles to fall asleep, and then complains that he is tired the next day.  The patient used to regularly attend soccer practice and spend time with friends afterward but recently said that he is "bad at" the sport and wants to quit the team.  A teacher has expressed concern that his grades have dropped from a B to a C average, that he is not engaged in class, and that his work has become "sloppy."  When interviewed without his mother present, the patient says, "I just wish people would leave me alone."  The patient does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  Vital signs are normal, and physical examination shows no abnormalities.  He makes poor eye contact and fidgets with his clothes.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This pediatric patient's behavioral changes, marked by an irritable mood and withdrawal from social activities together with poor sleep, poor appetite, impaired concentration, and psychomotor agitation (restlessness, fidgeting), are consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD).

As children move into adolescence and explore their autonomy and identity, they may engage in limit-testing and a desire to spend time with peers rather than family.  However, a marked change from baseline, with social withdrawal from peers and declining academic performance, as in this case, should prompt concern for a primary psychiatric illness and not be dismissed as age-appropriate behavior (Choice E).  Pediatric depression may present with symptoms of irritability, annoyance, and argumentative behavior rather than depressed mood.  Identification and appropriate treatment are important to decrease distress and limit impairment in social, emotional, and academic development, as well as to decrease the risk of suicide.

(Choice A)  Although starting middle school can be a significant stressor, the severity of symptoms and degree of impairment in this patient make MDD more likely than adjustment disorder.  Adjustment disorder is not diagnosed when the criteria for another psychiatric disorder, such as MDD, are met.

(Choice B)  Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder would not explain this patient's poor sleep, poor appetite, or social withdrawal.  Impaired concentration, distractibility, and psychomotor changes (agitation in this case) are common manifestations of depression.

(Choice C)  In disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, patients also have irritable mood.  However, this is accompanied by repetitive temper outbursts (verbal or physical) that are out of proportion to the stimulus and inconsistent with developmental level.  Symptoms manifest prior to age 10.

(Choice F)  Oppositional defiant disorder presents with an irritable or angry mood accompanied by deliberately annoying behavior, defiance of rules, and vindictiveness.  It would not explain poor sleep, poor appetite, or social withdrawal.  This child's defiance is likely a result of his irritability rather than being deliberate in nature.

Educational objective:
Pediatric major depression may present with irritability rather than depressed mood.  If a patient displays irritability along with social withdrawal and academic decline, major depression should be considered.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Child and adolescent mental health

answerChoiceList.choice: Adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Screening for depression in children and adolescents: U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement.

questionList.questionText:
A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend due to confusion.  The boyfriend says that the patient "seemed okay" when he left for work this morning, but when he returned in the evening, she was disoriented and "acting like a drunk person"; she had also vomited "all over the bathroom."  The patient was recently fired due to interpersonal problems with other employees.  She has a history of bipolar disorder.  Medications include clonazepam, lithium, and quetiapine.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 16/min.  On physical examination, the patient is somnolent and has frequent fasciculations.  Pupils are equal and reactive.  During evaluation, she has a brief episode of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin13 g/dL
    Platelets300,000/mm3
    Leukocytes9,000/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium136 mEq/L
    Potassium3.8 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate28 mEq/L
    Creatinine1.2 mg/dL
    Glucose120 mg/dL
    Blood alcoholnegative
    Serum lithium2.8 mEq/L (therapeutic range: 0.6-1.2)

Acetaminophen and salicylate are not detected in the serum, and urine drug screen is negative.  A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities.  In addition to supportive measures, which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is experiencing acute lithium toxicity.  Neurologic (eg, altered mental status, seizure, fasciculations, tremor) and gastrointestinal (eg, vomiting, diarrhea) signs are common in cases of acute intoxication.  Although mild overdoses can frequently be managed supportively with hydration and monitoring, hemodialysis is the treatment of choice for patients with lithium levels >2.5 mEq/L and prominent signs of toxicity.  Patients with levels >4 mEq/L and creatinine >2.0 mg/dL should generally be prescribed dialysis regardless of symptoms.

Because lithium is renally excreted, common precipitants of toxicity include medications that affect the excretion rate (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers) as well as dehydration by any cause (eg, diuretics, gastrointestinal illness).  Intentional overdose should also always be on the differential.

(Choices A and D)  Activated charcoal does not absorb cations such as lithium, and gastric lavage is ineffective for lithium toxicity.

(Choices B and F)  Calcium gluconate may be used in cases of hypocalcemia and hyperkalemia.  Magnesium sulfate is used in the treatment of hypomagnesemia, torsade de pointes, and preeclampsia.  They have no indication for use in lithium toxicity.

(Choice C)  Flumazenil, a selective GABA-A antagonist, is an antidotal therapy for benzodiazepine overdose but is rarely used because of the risk of seizures.  Manifestations of benzodiazepine overdose include slurred speech, ataxia, and depressed mental status with normal vital signs; fasciculations and gastrointestinal symptoms would be uncommon.

(Choice G)  Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as antidotal therapy for anticholinergic poisoning.  Anticholinergic poisoning can cause confusion (eg, mad as a hatter) but would also cause vasodilation (eg, red as a beet), anhidrosis (eg, dry as a bone), nonreactive mydriasis (eg, blind as a bat), and hallucinations (eg, mad as a hatter) with tachycardia and absent/decreased bowel sounds.

Educational objective:
Lithium toxicity presents with neurologic (eg, altered mental status, seizure, fasciculations, tremor) and gastrointestinal (eg, vomiting, diarrhea) signs.  The treatment of choice is hemodialysis.

Lithium poisoning.

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office with her mother for follow-up 1 week after a prolonged hospitalization for an acute asthma exacerbation.  The patient is taking inhaled albuterol and an oral corticosteroid, and her respiratory symptoms have improved significantly.  Her mother states that since hospital discharge, the girl has been acting strangely.  She is "talking over people instead of listening" and is unable to sit still.  The patient also has started to ignore requests to complete her daily chores and has been refusing dinner because she is "too busy" with organizing a school club for environmental protection.  She says she has been under a lot of pressure due to upcoming final exams but now feels "better than ever," explaining how she will have more time to "save the oceans and Mother Earth" after she is done studying.  The patient has a history of depression and takes sertraline.  She has used marijuana occasionally but does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other illicit drugs.  Vital signs are within normal limits, and cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities.  The patient appears impatient and checks her watch frequently throughout the evaluation.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's acute onset of hypomanic symptoms that include elevated mood, hyperactivity, talkativeness, goal-directed activity, and grandiosity (believing she can save the earth) in the context of corticosteroid use is suggestive of a medication-induced mood disorder.  In the case of new-onset psychiatric symptoms, it is essential to rule out medical and substance-induced causes.  This patient's symptoms developed suddenly after a prolonged hospitalization for an asthmatic episode in which high-dose corticosteroids were likely administered.

The psychiatric and cognitive effects of glucocorticoids may be mild and include euphoria, irritability, restlessness, anxiety, and sleep disturbance.  Severe effects are more common with high doses or prolonged use and include depression, hypomania (as in this case) or mania, psychosis, and confusion.  Mood symptoms typically resolve after the offending agent is discontinued.

(Choice A)  Acute stress disorder is characterized by symptoms of intrusive re-experiencing, avoidance, dissociation, and arousal lasting for ≤4 weeks in response to a traumatic event.

(Choice B)  Adjustment disorder is diagnosed when an individual responds to a stressor with an emotional and/or behavioral disturbance that does not meet criteria for a more specific disorder, such as medication-induced mood disorder (as in this patient).

(Choices C and D)  Diagnosis of bipolar II and related primary psychiatric disorders requires that hypomania not be caused by substances or medication.  Cyclothymia requires a duration of ≥1 year in adolescents (≥ 2 years in adults) and involves cyclical mood disturbances that do not meet all criteria for a full-blown depressive or hypomanic episode.  The diagnosis of bipolar II disorder requires ≥1 hypomanic episode and ≥1 depressive episode.

(Choice F)  Although adolescents may be impulsive, overconfident, and limit-testing, this girl's acute onset of behavioral changes representing a marked change from her baseline is more likely due to a medication-induced mood disorder.

Educational objective:
Evaluation of new-onset mood symptoms requires that medical and substance-induced causes be ruled out.  The neuropsychiatric side effects of glucocorticoids include euphoria, depression, hypomania or mania, and psychosis.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Substance induced mood disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Adverse consequences of glucocorticoid medication: psychological, cognitive, and behavioral effects.
Suicidal behavior and severe neuropsychiatric disorders following glucocorticoid therapy in primary care.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling from a fourth-floor balcony of his apartment building.  A witness at the scene reported that the patient stood on the balcony ledge for several minutes beforehand, looking down toward the street.  His fall was broken by a tree, and he sustained multiple minor injuries, including abrasions and lacerations to his face and the extremities.  The patient explains that he had a couple of beers and lost his balance while he was birdwatching.  He has no medical history but reports that he has lost some weight and feels tired because he cannot sleep due to the loud street noise in his neighborhood.  He lives alone and is worried about not being able to pay the rent if he does not find work soon.  The patient drinks 3 beers on most weekdays and 4 or 5 beers on weekends but does not use illicit drugs.  His vital signs, complete blood count, and comprehensive metabolic panel are within normal limits.  Blood alcohol concentration is 0.005%.  The patient's lacerations are sutured, and he is medically cleared.  Mental status examination shows a thin, anxious man who is cooperative and oriented to person, place, and time.  The patient makes poor eye contact and gives brief responses, repeatedly insisting, "Everything's fine, I'm okay.  I just want to go home."  He says he is not suicidal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Patients sometimes deny that they have made a suicide attempt, due to either stigmatization or a desire to reattempt.  The physician has a duty to assess the likelihood that an attempt has been made and the risk for further self-harm.  Despite his denial, this patient has likely attempted suicide and is at high risk for a repeated attempt.  He has numerous risk factors for suicide, including features suggestive of depression (weight loss, poor sleep, anxious affect), unemployment, living alone, risk of homelessness (eg, worried about paying rent), and active substance use, as well as a likely recent attempt.

Physicians should use their clinical judgment when assessing suicide risk and must always act to ensure patient safety.  This patient should be hospitalized for his own protection, on involuntary status if necessary.  It would be inappropriate and unsafe to manage his condition in an outpatient setting.

(Choices A, B, and F)  This patient should be hospitalized immediately for safety reasons.  Although he may benefit from antidepressant therapy, psychotherapy, and social services, these interventions must initially take place in a supervised hospital setting due to his high suicide risk.

(Choice D)  Holding the patient for observation in the emergency department (ED) is indicated when factors are expected to resolve after a short period, making hospitalization unnecessary (eg, alcohol intoxication).  This patient's blood alcohol concentration is negligible with no indication of an altered mental state.  His suicide risk factors will not resolve in 24 hours without further intervention, and he should not be held in the ED unnecessarily, which would delay treatment.

(Choice E)  Although this patient's alcohol use should be addressed because it contributes to disinhibition and increases suicide risk, the priority is to ensure his safety.

Educational objective:
It is a physician's duty to use clinical judgment when assessing suicide risk.  Even if a patient denies a suicide attempt, when a likely attempt has been made and the risk of further self-harm remains high, the patient must be hospitalized (involuntarily if necessary) to ensure safety.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Suicide

answerChoiceList.choice: Arrange outpatient psychiatric follow-up for the following day
Discuss options for antidepressant therapy and recommend outpatient psychotherapy
Observe the patient in the emergency department for 24 hours and then reassess
Perform a brief intervention for alcohol use
Refer the patient to social services

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Civil commitment in the United States.

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother due to concern about her behavior and grades.  Her mother says, "She used to be a good student, but over the past few months, her grades have dropped, and she doesn't seem to care."  The patient has been in the annual school play since first grade but recently quit the drama club because "I am not into it anymore; I can't even remember the lines anyway."  She avoids her friends and spends a great deal of time in her room with the door locked.  She goes to bed early, wakes up late, and takes naps of 1-2 hours when she gets home from school because she feels tired.  Her mother reports that the patient has been more irritable, fighting frequently with her younger siblings.  The patient responds, "I'm the oldest and my brothers annoy me all the time.  I just don't have any privacy at home!"  She has no medical conditions and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  The patient is cooperative but appears distracted at times and asks for several questions to be repeated.  She appears fidgety and restless, frequently shifting in her seat and shaking her right leg.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Major depressive disorder

Diagnosis

  • ≥5 of the following symptoms lasting ≥2 weeks (at least 1 symptom must be either depressed mood or loss of interest/pleasure):
    • Depressed mood
    • Loss of interest or pleasure
    • Change in appetite or weight
    • Insomnia or hypersomnia
    • Psychomotor retardation or agitation
    • Low energy
    • Poor concentration or indecisiveness
    • Thoughts of worthlessness or inappropriate guilt
    • Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide
  • No history of mania or hypomania
  • Not due to substances or another medical condition

This patient has several findings suggestive of major depressive disorder, including the following:

  • Loss of motivation and decreased interest (anhedonia) in school and activities she used to enjoy (eg, drama club, time with peers)
  • Sleep changes (eg, hypersomnia)
  • Lack of energy (eg, fatigue despite sleeping more)
  • Poor concentration (difficulty remembering lines, need for questions to be repeated)
  • Extreme irritability
  • Psychomotor agitation (fidgeting, restlessness)

Like this patient, depressed adolescents may be irritable rather than sad.  The degree of functional impairment at school and in relationships must be assessed in adolescents with suspected major depressive disorder.  Although adolescents are frequently moody and desire privacy, this patient's behavior represents a marked change from her baseline.  Her symptoms are causing significant academic dysfunction and social impairment inconsistent with normal adolescent behavior (Choice E).

Other symptoms of major depressive disorder include changes in appetite or weight loss/gain, excessive guilt/feelings of worthlessness, and suicidal ideation.  Treatment of adolescent depression consists of psychotherapy and, in severe cases, antidepressants (eg, fluoxetine).

(Choice A)  Although stressful life events often play a role in precipitating behavioral changes, adjustment disorder is not diagnosed if the symptoms are severe enough to meet the criteria for major depressive disorder.

(Choice B)  Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder has a chronic course and requires onset of symptoms prior to age 12.  This patient's impaired concentration and fidgeting are symptoms of her depression.

(Choice C)  Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is characterized by persistent irritability and frequent temper outbursts that begin prior to age 10; they are grossly out of proportion to the situation and inconsistent with developmental level.  This disorder is not diagnosed when irritability and outbursts occur as part of a depressive episode.

Educational objective:
Adolescent depression may be characterized by irritability; loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities; fatigue; disturbances in sleep, concentration, and appetite; excessive guilt/feelings of worthlessness; and suicidal ideation.  The severity of symptoms and related impairment can help differentiate depression from adjustment disorder and normal adolescent behavior.

answerChoiceList.choice: Adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct
