questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old man comes to the office saying, "I'm just not feeling like myself."  This change began soon after his older brother died of cancer 3 months ago.  The patient feels sad and has lost interest in work and going out with friends on weekends.  He falls asleep relatively easily at night but awakens very early in the morning and is unable to fall back asleep.  The patient feels "very down," especially when he first wakes up, but says that his mood improves a little during the day when he is busy.  His poor energy and concentration have started to affect his performance at work, and he frequently thinks that, "I should just quit because I am bringing everyone down."  He has been eating less and has lost 5.4 kg (12 lb) over the past few weeks.  The patient has had no suicidal thoughts.  He has no psychiatric history other than counseling as a teenager when his parents divorced.  The patient mentions that he had been close to his brother when they were growing up, but they drifted apart as adults.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Major depressive episode & grief reaction

Major depressive episode

Grief reaction

  • ≥2 weeks; ≥5 of 9 symptoms: low mood, anhedonia, sleep disturbance, appetite change, low energy, psychomotor changes, guilt/worthlessness, concentration difficulty, suicidal ideation
  • May occur in response to a variety of stressors, including loss of a loved one
  • Marked social & occupational dysfunction
  • Suicidality related to hopelessness & worthlessness
  • Normal reaction to loss (bereavement)
  • Sadness more specific to thoughts of the deceased 
  • "Waves" of grief at reminders
  • Self-esteem usually preserved
  • Functional decline less severe
  • Thoughts of dying involve wish to join the deceased; active suicidality uncommon
  • Intensity decreases over time

Although this patient's depressive symptoms developed in response to the stressor of bereavement, his symptoms are sufficient in number, duration, and severity to meet diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode (ie, depressed mood, loss of interest, early morning awakening, weight loss, low energy, impaired concentration lasting ≥2 weeks).  Patients with ≥1 major depressive episode and no history of mania or hypomania are diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD).  DSM-5 allows for the diagnosis of MDD during the bereavement period because evidence has shown that bereavement-related major depression and major depression not related to bereavement have a similar course and response to treatment.  The death of a loved one is similar to any other serious stressor that can trigger a major depressive episode.

Major depression can be difficult to differentiate from acute grief.  In a normal grief reaction, sadness is typically focused on the deceased and decreases in intensity over several weeks, with intermittent waves of grief mixed with positive memories (Choice D).  A major depressive episode involves more persistent sadness and pervasive anhedonia (as in this patient).  Excessive guilt, self-critical ruminations, and suicidality related to feelings of worthlessness and hopelessness can also help distinguish MDD from normal grief.

(Choice A)  Acute stress disorder develops within one month of a traumatic event and is characterized by intrusive re-experiencing (eg, flashbacks, intense memories), negative mood and cognitions, avoidance, and hyperarousal.

(Choice B)  Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is characterized by depressive symptoms that develop in response to a stressor.  However, symptoms should not represent normal bereavement and cannot be diagnosed when criteria are met for another disorder, such as MDD in this patient.

(Choice E)  Persistent complex bereavement disorder (also called complicated grief) is characterized by persistent yearning for the deceased and prolonged emotional pain related to the loss.  It is accompanied by maladaptive, ruminative thoughts and dysfunctional behaviors.  This patient's depression does not revolve around yearning for his brother.

Educational objective:
Major depressive disorder can be diagnosed if depressive symptoms following the loss of a loved one are sufficiently severe to meet diagnostic criteria.  Compared to normal grief, major depression is associated with more persistent and pervasive sadness, feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness, and suicidal ideation.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old man with a history of bipolar disorder since age 27 comes to the office for follow-up.  The patient was hospitalized 2 years ago for a manic episode and was discharged with a therapeutic dose of lithium; he continues to take the same dose and is engaged in weekly psychotherapy.  The patient says, "This is the best I've felt in years; work is going great, and I'm getting married in a few months.  I really don't want to get hospitalized again, but I also don't want to keep taking medication if I don't have to."  Prior medication trials include quetiapine and olanzapine with fluoxetine; both treatments were discontinued due to weight gain.  Medical history is noncontributory.  Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable.  The patient appears euthymic and has a full range of affect.  Complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and TSH are within normal limits; serum lithium level is within therapeutic range.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Bipolar disorder is a highly recurrent illness, and multiple mood episodes are typical.  The goal of maintenance treatment is to decrease the risk for recurrent manic and depressive episodes that can severely impair functioning and relationships.  Lithium is a first-line agent that has been studied extensively and helps decrease rates of relapse in patients with bipolar disorder.  Discontinuing stable lithium treatment usually leads to a recurrent episode within months to a year and carries risks of hospitalization, economic losses, and suicide.

Understanding the patient's reasons for not wanting to be on medication and responding to any specific concerns he has about lithium are important.  However, treatment recommendations must take into account the high risk of recurrent episodes.  This patient is doing well on a therapeutic dose of lithium (ie, no recurrent manic or depressive episodes since starting lithium 2 years ago) and is tolerating the medication without difficulty.  His medication history indicates that other treatment options (ie, quetiapine, olanzapine with fluoxetine) resulted in unacceptable weight gain.  The most appropriate response is to recommend continuing lithium at the same dose while monitoring for side effects.  An analogy can be made to other chronic illnesses (eg, asthma) that may require prolonged medication usage.

(Choice A)  Because bipolar disorder is a highly recurrent illness, tapering off medication is not recommended.

(Choice C)  Lowering the dose of lithium is sometimes done to manage side effects.  This patient's lithium dose is in the therapeutic range, and he is tolerating the medication without adverse effects; lowering the dose may result in a subtherapeutic dose and increase his risk for recurrence.

(Choice D)  Long-acting injectable antipsychotic agents (eg haloperidol, aripiprazole, risperidone) can be considered for maintenance treatment in bipolar disorder and can be especially useful for improving adherence.  However, they are third-line agents typically used in patients who tolerated oral formulations.  This patient is doing well on lithium, with a therapeutic blood level indicating adherence.  Changing to a long-acting injectable is not indicated and may result in destabilization (eg, lag before reaching therapeutic levels) or be associated with side effects.

Educational objective:
Bipolar disorder is a highly recurrent illness.  Maintenance treatment is recommended to decrease the risk of recurrent manic or depressive episodes.  Lithium therapy should be maintained in patients whose condition is stable and who are tolerating the medication.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bipolar disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: "Mood episodes are often triggered by stress or change; let's continue the medication for now and begin tapering it after your wedding."
"Mood episodes in bipolar disorder are highly recurrent; I suggest continuing lithium at the current dose and monitoring for side effects."
"Since you have had no mood episodes in the past 2 years and you meet regularly for therapy, it would be reasonable to decrease your dose."
"We can try switching to a medication that you don't have to take daily; let's talk about the available long-acting injectable treatments."

questionList.questionText: A 52-year-old man comes to the office due to low energy and poor sleep.  The patient reports feeling stressed since his divorce last year.  He has difficulty sleeping through the night and awakens around 4:00 AM most mornings, earlier than he would like.  At work, the patient is unable to concentrate and has become less productive.  Although he loves his children, he no longer enjoys visiting them on the weekends and makes excuses to stay home.  The patient says that food is tasteless, and his appetite has decreased significantly over the past 2 months.  Blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min.  Physical examination is normal.  Mental status examination shows a depressed and anxious mood, with mild psychomotor agitation.  He has no psychotic features or suicidal ideation.  This patient is most likely to have which of the following abnormalities?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient meets the criteria for major depressive disorder with his evident depressed mood, anhedonia, decreased appetite, early-morning awakening insomnia, low energy, impaired concentration, and psychomotor agitation.  Hyperactivity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, resulting in increased cortisol levels (without signs/symptoms of Cushing syndrome), has been associated with depression.

The neurocytotoxic effects of hypercortisolemia may play an important role in the pathogenesis of depressive symptoms and associated cognitive deficits.  These effects may also explain the association of stress and trauma with the increased risk for development of depression.  Other findings in patients with depression include glucocorticoid-mediated decreased hippocampal volume and suppressed neural connection.

Effective psychotherapy for depression (ie, cognitive-behavioral therapy, interpersonal therapy) incorporates stress reduction into treatment, whereas antidepressant pharmacotherapy promotes neural plasticity to restore damaged pathways.  It is suspected that the improved intrapersonal and interpersonal functioning and enhanced social support from therapy influence and augment the antidepressant-mediated plasticity.

(Choice A)  Although hippocampal atrophy can be seen in depression, enlarged lateral cerebral ventricles are more commonly associated with schizophrenia.

(Choices B and E)  REM sleep latency (ie, time from sleep onset until the start of the first REM sleep period) is decreased, not increased, in depression.  In addition, slow-wave sleep (ie, deep sleep) is decreased, not increased, in depression.

(Choice C)  Lactate infusion can provoke panic attacks in susceptible patients and has been used in research to identify those with panic disorder.

Educational objective:
Major depressive disorder is associated with hyperactivity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, resulting in increased cortisol levels.  Antidepressants and psychotherapy may restore the emotional processing pathways damaged by cortisol.

questionList.title: Depression

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The neurobiological mechanisms and treatments of REM sleep disturbances in depression.
The cortisol awakening response and major depression: examining the evidence.

questionList.questionText: A 59-year-old man comes to the office due to worsening depression and insomnia since his wife died 7 months ago from cancer.  The patient is frequently tearful and is no longer interested in socializing with his married friends.  He has attended 3 sessions of supportive psychotherapy and expresses appreciation for the referral because he likes the therapist.  However, he continues to feel depressed and is now experiencing severe insomnia.  The patient has difficulty falling and staying asleep, frequently lying awake at night thinking about his wife.  He feels very guilty about her death and believes that he should have done more for her during her final months.  His appetite is poor and he says it is easier to buy prepared foods than cook for himself.  Last week, the patient experienced a moment of severe depression in which he briefly thought that he would be better off dead.  However, he insists that he would never act on these thoughts.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination is unremarkable aside from a 3.6-kg (8-lb) weight loss since his wife's death.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Although there is considerable symptom overlap between grief reactions and major depression, this patient's worsening depression is concerning.  His symptoms meet the criteria for a major depressive episode and include depressed mood, loss of interest, insomnia, guilt, low energy, weight loss, and thoughts of death.  A major depressive episode is diagnosed regardless of an existing precipitant, including bereavement.

Appropriate first-line treatment of major depression includes antidepressant medication and psychotherapy.  Although selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are commonly used as a first choice for the treatment of depressive disorders, mirtazapine would be a preferred choice for this patient with poor sleep and appetite.  Mirtazapine is a first-line antidepressant medication whose side effects include stimulation of appetite, weight gain, and somnolence.

(Choices A, B, and G)  This patient's symptoms are more severe and persistent than would be expected in a normal grief reaction.  Although he appears to have a good relationship with his therapist, his depression is worsening.  Educating the patient about grief, continuing/increasing the frequency of psychotherapy, or adding a grief support group would not adequately address his worsening depressive symptoms (ie, weight loss, marked insomnia, passive suicidal ideation).

(Choice C)  Tricyclic antidepressants (eg, amitriptyline) are not considered first-line treatment due to significant anticholinergic side effects, orthostatic hypotension, and cardiotoxicity in overdose.

(Choice E)  Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine sleep medication that would not adequately treat this patient's underlying depression.

(Choice F)  Electroconvulsive therapy is used mainly for patients who do not respond to antidepressants and for severely depressed patients who are catatonic, psychotic, acutely suicidal, or not eating or drinking.  This patient's condition is less severe and would benefit from initial antidepressant treatment.

Educational objective:
Bereaved patients who develop moderate to severe major depression should be considered for treatment with both psychotherapy and antidepressants.  Mirtazapine is a preferred choice for patients with marked insomnia and weight loss due to its side effects of appetite stimulation and sedation.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Depression

answerChoiceList.choice: Educate the patient regarding the course of grief and continue psychotherapy
Increase the frequency of psychotherapy sessions to twice weekly
Prescribe zolpidem for insomnia and continue psychotherapy
Refer to a grief support group and continue psychotherapy

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Symptom and functional traits of brief major depressive episodes and discrimination of bereavement.
Review of the use of mirtazapine in the treatment of depression.

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to concern about a change in his behavior.  Over the past 3 months he has become more withdrawn, spending more time alone and turning down opportunities to socialize with his friends.  He is frequently moody and irritable.  The patient feels unmotivated at school and seems unconcerned that his grades have dropped.  His parents believe that his behavior changed after he was rejected by a girl, who subsequently called him a "loser" on social media.  When seen alone, the patient says, "I don't think I will ever get over this girl," who he believes was his "soul mate."  He uses marijuana occasionally but does not use alcohol.  Physical examination is normal apart from a 2.7-kg (6-lb) weight loss since his last visit.  He says, "I feel pretty down.  I would consider talking to someone or taking medication but don't want to worry my parents."  Which of the following is the most appropriate step prior to initiating treatment for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient shows signs and symptoms concerning for depression (eg, social isolation, lack of motivation, irritable mood, academic decline, weight loss).  Before initiating treatment, a suicide-risk assessment must be performed because it could have immediate implications for safety and for determining the appropriate treatment setting.  The physician should ask specific questions in a direct and nonjudgmental manner.  These include: Do you wish you were dead?  Are you having thoughts about harming or killing yourself?  Have you made any plans or preparations to kill yourself?  Have you ever tried to kill yourself?

Suicide is a leading cause of death in adolescents.  The combination of depression (particularly in the setting of rejection and humiliation/cyberbullying) and impulsivity (which is characteristic of adolescence) places this patient at increased risk and should not be underestimated.  Confidentiality should not be promised because it cannot be maintained if there is a concern for safety (Choice A).  Depending on the assessment, this patient may require immediate psychiatric evaluation in the emergency department and/or hospitalization.

(Choices B, D, and G)  Although parental consent is required to prescribe medication, and it is important to respond to this patient's interest in treatment, it is premature to recommend treatment with antidepressants and/or psychotherapy prior to completing a thorough assessment.

(Choice C)  Although adolescents should be encouraged to involve their parents in decision-making, the priority in this case is to determine if the patient is a danger to himself.  If there is any concern for the patient's safety, the parents must be informed with or without consent.

(Choice F)  This patient has had persistent depressive symptoms for 3 months and should not simply be reassured.  A thorough evaluation for depression, including careful screening for suicidal thoughts, is necessary.

Educational objective:
Suicide-risk assessment in adolescents should include direct and nonjudgmental questions to determine the nature and intensity of suicidal thoughts.  Confidentiality should not be promised because it cannot be maintained if the patient is at high risk for self-harm.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Child and adolescent mental health

answerChoiceList.choice: Assure the patient that everything he says is confidential
Discuss the risks and benefits of psychotherapy versus medication
Encourage the patient to tell his parents how he feels
Inform the patient that parental permission is needed to prescribe medication
Inquire if the patient has thoughts of harming himself
Reassure the patient that sadness is normal after a romantic breakup
Recommend psychotherapy in addition to medication

questionList.questionText: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department accompanied by her son due to worsening depression for the past few weeks.  She has recurrent major depressive disorder and a prior suicide attempt.  The patient was taking venlafaxine with good response until a month ago, when she discontinued it because she felt it was "unnecessary."  Her son, whom she lives with, noticed that she has become more withdrawn, staying in her bedroom and preferring to sit in the dark watching television instead of sleeping.  The patient has been refusing meals to "sacrifice" herself for "the greater good" and repeatedly tells her son that she "must die in accordance with the divine plan."  Height is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in), and weight is 49 kg (108 lb).  BMI is 18 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor and dry mucous membranes.  On mental status examination, her clothes are stained and malodorous.  The patient makes minimal eye contact and looks at the floor for most of the evaluation.  She does not respond to most questions, although she correctly states her name, birthdate, and today's date.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Electroconvulsive therapy for depression

Indications

  • Treatment resistance
  • Psychotic features
  • Emergency conditions
    • Pregnancy
    • Refusal to eat or drink
    • Imminent risk for suicide

Safety

  • No absolute contraindications
  • Increased risk 
    • Severe cardiovascular disease,
      recent myocardial infarction
    • Space-occupying brain lesion
    • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

This patient's worsening depressive symptoms, extreme functional decline, and meal refusal to "sacrifice" herself for "the greater good" while insisting that she "must die in accordance with the divine plan" is consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD) with psychotic features.  Psychotic features may be subtle or intermittent but often include delusions and/or hallucinations with depressive themes of deserved punishment, guilt, worthlessness, and/or catastrophe.

First-line treatment of psychotic depression consists of either an antidepressant plus an antipsychotic or electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) alone.  However, MDD with psychotic features progresses to a suicide attempt in up to 25% of patients.  Therefore, when suicidality presents in this population, it should be treated aggressively; ECT can provide a rapid reduction in symptoms.

In this scenario, the patient's psychotic depression with suicidal motivation to her meal restriction resulted in physical manifestations of dehydration (eg, decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes), with likely significant weight loss.  She should be offered inpatient psychiatric treatment so ECT can be pursued.  ECT is a safe and effective procedure and has no absolute contraindications.  It is typically administered 3 times a week for a course of 6-12 treatments.

(Choices A and D)  Clozapine is an antipsychotic primarily reserved for use in treatment-resistant schizophrenia due to the risk for agranulocytosis.  Olanzapine is an effective antipsychotic that can stimulate appetite to increase oral intake.  However, antipsychotic monotherapy is insufficient.  An antidepressant plus an antipsychotic is necessary to treat MDD with psychotic features.

(Choices C, E, and F)  Mirtazapine is an antidepressant that can stimulate appetite to increase oral intake.  Venlafaxine is a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, and sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that can be augmented with the dopamine norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor bupropion.  These antidepressants are indicated in the treatment of MDD.  However, antidepressant therapy alone is insufficient for MDD with psychotic features, and the prolonged time to effectiveness makes ECT a better option.

Educational objective:
Electroconvulsive therapy is a safe and effective first-line treatment for major depressive disorder with psychotic features.  It is particularly appropriate for severely depressed patients who refuse to eat and drink or are acutely suicidal.

questionList.questionText: A 46-year-old man with a history of medication-controlled hypertension comes to the office for a routine checkup.  Blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg and physical examination findings are normal.  The physician notes that the patient's mood seems low.  The patient admits that he has been "stressed out" for the past 2 months as a few people at work recently quit and he has had to take on more responsibility while management finds replacements.  He has not been able to exercise or eat right as he is so busy.  The patient feels irritable and tense at work and has had neck and shoulder pain.  He is also worried about not being able to spend time with his wife, who complains that he works too much.  The patient has occasional difficulty falling asleep at night after working long hours and feels tired during the day.  Although he doesn't enjoy his job, he has no choice but to stay.  He continues to get his work done and enjoys social activities, including playing golf on weekends.  The patient drinks 2-3 cans of beer on weekends and smokes marijuana twice a month.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Differential diagnosis of depressed mood

Major depressive disorder

  • ≥2 weeks
  • ≥5 of 9 symptoms: depressed mood & SIGECAPS
  • Significant functional impairment
  • No lifetime history of mania

Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia)

  • Chronic depressed mood ≥2 years
  • ≥2 of the following: appetite disturbance, sleep disturbance, low energy, low self-esteem, poor concentration, hopelessness

Adjustment disorder with depressed mood

  • Onset within 3 months of identifiable stressor
  • Marked distress &/or functional impairment
  • Does not meet criteria for another DSM-5-TR disorder

Normal stress response

  • Not excessive or out of proportion to severity of stressor
  • No significant functional impairment

SIGECAPS = Sleep disturbance, loss of Interest, excessive Guilt, low Energy, impaired Concentration, Appetite disturbance, Psychomotor agitation/retardation, and Suicidal ideation. 

This patient's symptoms in response to his stressful work situation (eg, mood appears low, poor sleep, fatigue) are consistent with a normal stress response.  His symptoms are mild rather than excessive given the nature of the stressor; he does not meet the full criteria for any disorder; and he is not markedly distressed (eg, does not himself bring the subject up with the physician).  Most importantly, the patient exhibits no impairment of social and occupational functioning, a key feature of psychiatric illness.  This patient continues to function well (eg, still performs at work, enjoys socializing and leisure activities).

(Choice A)  Acute stress disorder is characterized by symptoms of reexperiencing (intrusive memories and flashbacks), avoidance, negative mood, dissociation, and hyperarousal lasting from 3 days to 1 month following a traumatic event.

(Choice B)  In adjustment disorder with depressed mood, depressive symptoms develop within 3 months of the onset of an identifiable stressor.  In contrast to a normal stress response, it involves marked distress out of proportion to the stressor and/or impaired social or occupational functioning.

(Choice C)  Irritability, tension, and poor sleep can be seen in generalized anxiety disorder; however, this diagnosis requires excessive worries about multiple issues and duration of ≥6 months.

(Choice D)  Diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder include a 2-week period of at least 5 of 9 symptoms:  Depressed mood + Sleep disturbance, loss of Interest, excessive Guilt, low Energy, impaired Concentration, loss of Appetite, Psychomotor agitation/retardation, and Suicidal ideation (SIGECAPS mnemonic).  This diagnosis requires significant functional impairment and may be given regardless of an identifiable precipitant.

(Choice F)  Although medication- or substance-induced depressive symptoms should be ruled out, there is no evidence to suggest that this patient's medication or substance use is causing his symptoms, which seem etiologically connected to his work situation.  Antihypertensives seldom cause depression.

Educational objective:
Patients with situationally triggered depressive symptoms should be assessed for major depressive and adjustment disorders.  Normal stress reactions are distinguished by lower severity and absence of marked distress or significant functional impairment.

questionList.title: Adjustment disorders

questionList.questionText: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up of major depressive disorder.  She was first seen 2 weeks ago for low mood and irritability, loss of interest, difficulty falling and staying asleep, decreased appetite, and poor concentration at work.  At that time, she was started on a therapeutic dosage of escitalopram and weekly psychotherapy.  The patient had mild nausea for several days after starting the medication but is now tolerating it without difficulty.  She says, "I'm afraid the medication isn't working as well anymore.  At first my sleep and appetite were better, but for the past few days I feel like I might be slipping back to where I started."  The patient reports that she is stressed because her husband is away on business this week and her father was recently hospitalized for a stroke.  Mental status examination shows a mildly depressed mood and sad affect.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacological management?
questionList.explanationText:
Assessment of antidepressant medication response requires that the patient has had an adequate trial in both dose and duration.  An adequate antidepressant trial is generally considered to be at least 4-6 weeks at a therapeutic dosage.  This patient has taken escitalopram for only 2 weeks, which is considered an inadequate trial in duration.  Her lack of sustained improvement after 2 weeks is not uncommon, and her symptoms over the past week are likely related in part to psychosocial stress (father hospitalized, husband away).

The most appropriate step in pharmacotherapy is to continue the trial of escitalopram at the current dosage.  Increasing the dosage is unnecessary and risks exposing the patient to additional side effects (Choice E).  The patient should be educated that 2 weeks is considered an inadequate trial and encouraged to continue the medication for at least 2-4 more weeks.  Patients should receive an adequate antidepressant trial before next-step treatments are recommended, such as augmentation with a second medication or switching to an alternate antidepressant.

(Choices A and B)  It would be premature to add amitriptyline at bedtime or aripiprazole after only 2 weeks of escitalopram.  These augmentation strategies could be considered in a patient who has failed an adequate trial of monotherapy.

(Choices C and D)  Discontinuing antidepressant medication at the 2-week point would be premature.  Switching to an alternate antidepressant can be considered for patients with minimal response after an adequate trial of 4-6 weeks or for those unable to tolerate the medication.  Trazodone is a very sedating medication that is often difficult to tolerate in dosages required to treat depression.

Educational objective:
An antidepressant trial is at least 4-6 weeks at a therapeutic dose.  Physicians should continue antidepressants for at least 4-6 weeks before considering the next step in treatment.

questionList.title: Antidepressants

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old man comes to the office due to persistent sadness, weight gain, and fatigue over the past 4 months.  The patient is a dentist who has had difficulty waking up in the morning for clinic.  He says, "I used to be really efficient, but now I always run 2 hours behind schedule."  He has been eating "lots of fast food" for dinner and feels exhausted every day.  Following a divorce 3 years ago, the patient was diagnosed with major depressive disorder, which improved after a few months of treatment with paroxetine.  The patient has a history of separation anxiety disorder as a child, which resolved with psychotherapy.  Family history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder in his mother.  Physical examination and laboratory evaluation are normal.  After discussion of treatment options, the patient decides to start sertraline.  His symptoms resolve by the follow-up appointment 6 months later.  Which of the following features is an indication for long-term maintenance of antidepressant therapy in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
For many patients, major depressive disorder is a recurrent illness, as seen in this case.  Recommendations for long-term maintenance antidepressant therapy should take the number of lifetime depressive episodes into account because prior history of episodes is the most consistently identified risk factor for future episodes.

Patients with ≥2 episodes are candidates for maintenance antidepressant therapy (ie, continuing antidepressants for 1-3 years).  Continuing treatment indefinitely can also be considered in some cases (eg, ≥3 lifetime depressive episodes) .  Other indications for maintenance therapy include early age of onset, greater severity, suicidality, and the presence of severe, ongoing psychosocial stressors or persistent residual depressive symptoms.

In contrast to patients with recurrent episodes, patients with a single episode of major depressive disorder should continue antidepressant treatment for a period of 6 months following response.  If remission is sustained, the antidepressant can then be tapered and discontinued.

(Choice A)  Early age of onset (<20 years) is a risk factor for recurrence.

(Choice B)  Chronic depressive episodes (lasting >2 years) are an indication for maintenance therapy.  However, this patient's current and prior depressive episodes lasted only a few months.

(Choice C)  A link between family history of anxiety disorders and the risk of recurrence of mood episodes has not been demonstrated.

(Choice D)  Patients who have an active comorbid psychiatric disorder or a history of childhood abuse are at an increased risk for depressive recurrence.  However, this patient has no history of abuse, and his history of separation anxiety disorder is remote.

(Choice F)  There is no evidence that the presence of atypical depressive features (eg, hypersomnia, hyperphagia, mood reactivity) increases the risk of recurrence.

Educational objective:
Major depressive disorder is frequently recurrent.  Long-term maintenance antidepressant therapy is indicated for patients with ≥2 major depressive episodes.

questionList.questionText: A 58-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after developing a headache following a gourmet meal that included heavy sauces and wine.  On arrival, the patient is anxious and tremulous.  Medical history includes recurrent major depression with psychotic features, generalized anxiety disorder, and osteoarthritis.  Medications include phenelzine and risperidone, which she takes as prescribed.  Her depression has been in remission for the past 5 years.  The patient's other medications include ibuprofen.  She does not use illicit drugs.  Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
questionList.explanationText:
The acute onset of headache following a meal in a patient treated with phenelzine raises concern for hypertensive crisis.  Phenelzine is one of several available monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), an older class of antidepressant drugs used primarily for the treatment of refractory depression.  In the brain, they inhibit the metabolism of the monoamines norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin.  MAOIs are not typically used as first-line therapy due to drug-drug interactions and dietary restrictions involving foods containing tyramine.

Tyramine may be present in aged cheeses, aged or cured meats, aged or fermented soy products, overripe fruits, and some alcoholic beverages.  Tyramine is a sympathomimetic monoamine that can facilitate the release of other sympathomimetic monoamines (eg, adrenaline/epinephrine) systemically.  Tyramine metabolism is inhibited in the presence of MAOIs, causing an increased sympathomimetic (ie, adrenergic) effect that can result in severe hypertension.  This commonly presents first as a headache but can lead to intracranial bleeding, stroke, and death.

(Choices A and F)  Hyperreflexia and myoclonus are characteristic of serotonin syndrome, which can occur when MAOIs are combined with serotonergic antidepressants, illicit substances, or other medications with serotonergic effects (eg, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, meperidine).  The combination of an MAOI and tyramine does not usually result in serotonin syndrome.

(Choice C)  Hyperthermia is not a typical feature of hypertensive crisis.

(Choice D)  Hypotension is a fairly common side effect of MAOIs and may lead to dizziness but is not related to any dietary interaction.

(Choice E)  Diffuse muscle rigidity is seen in neuroleptic malignant syndrome, a rare medical complication of antipsychotics that typically occurs early in treatment and would be unlikely to appear in a patient who has been on a stable dose of risperidone for years.

Educational objective:
Patients taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors such as phenelzine should avoid foods rich in tyramine as the interaction of such food-drug combinations can result in hypertensive crisis.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, comes to the office for evaluation of insomnia following the birth of her son 5 weeks ago.  The patient says she wakes up each night to breastfeed him but is unable to go back to sleep.  She stays up most of the night thinking, "Why did I have a child so late in life? I'm already failing as a mother."  The patient has a decreased appetite and no interest in seeing friends or family members other than her mother.  She has no medical history and the delivery was uncomplicated.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  On mental status examination, the patient appears restless and is tearful.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's insomnia, loss of appetite, lack of interest in seeing friends, depressed mood/tearfulness, restlessness (ie, psychomotor agitation), and guilt about her ability to care for her son are most likely due to a major depressive episode with postpartum onset.  Postpartum depression is diagnosed using the same diagnostic criteria for diagnosing a major depressive episode (≥2 weeks of at least 5 of 9 symptoms that include depressed mood plus SIGECAPS: Sleep disturbance, loss of Interest, Guilt/worthlessness, low Energy, impaired Concentration, change in Appetite, Psychomotor retardation or agitation, and Suicidal thoughts).  Comorbid anxiety is common in postpartum depression, frequently revolving around anxiety about the infant's health and concerns about being a good mother.  Screening for postpartum depression should be performed routinely at postpartum checkups.

In comparison to postpartum depression, postpartum blues is a more common condition characterized by mild depressive symptoms (eg, tearfulness, irritability) that develop 2-3 days following delivery (Choice E).  It is a normal and self-limited response that typically peaks at 5 days postpartum and resolves within 2 weeks.  In contrast, this patient's symptoms have persisted beyond 2 weeks and are sufficiently severe to diagnose a major depressive episode.

(Choice A)  Although being a new mother is a significant stressor, when symptoms are severe enough to meet criteria for a major depressive episode, adjustment disorder is not diagnosed.

(Choice B)  Postpartum medical complications (eg, anemia, thyroiditis) can cause mood symptoms.  However, this patient has a normal physical examination and no history of medical problems or obstetrical complications, making anxiety due to a medical condition less likely.

(Choice C)  This patient's anxiety revolves around her ability to care for her baby.  Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by pervasive anxiety about multiple issues that lasts ≥6 months.

Educational objective:
Postpartum depression should be differentiated from postpartum blues, a milder and self-limited form of depression that peaks at 5 days and resolves within 2 weeks.  Postpartum depression is diagnosed using the same diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode outside the postpartum period.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Depression

answerChoiceList.choice: Anxiety due to a general medical condition

Concise review for physicians and other clinicians: postpartum depression.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old man comes to the office at his wife's insistence due to issues with concentration that are affecting his job performance.  The patient works in information technology and has been easily distracted and unable to complete his assignments after returning from a business trip 4 weeks ago.  The trip was stressful because it involved giving multiple presentations.  Since his return, instead of working on current projects with assigned deadlines, he has spent hours developing new computer programs and is at risk of losing his job.  He hardly sleeps at night and is increasingly anxious and irritable, behavior that is uncharacteristic.  Last week, the patient became angry when his wife was skeptical of his idea to leave his job and start an internet company with no resources or investors.  The patient has a history of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, for which he was treated with cognitive-behavioral therapy for 4 years beginning at age 8.  He used cocaine in his early 20s but has not used illicit drugs in 3 years, apart from marijuana on occasion, which he says "helps me feel less anxious."  Family history is significant for depression in his mother.  On physical examination, the patient is cooperative but appears tense and anxious.  He is talkative, easily distracted, and has difficulty sitting still; at one point he gets up to walk around the room.  The patient has no psychotic symptoms or suicidal ideation.  Urine drug screen is negative.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's recent behavior?
questionList.explanationText:
Manic episode

Clinical
features

  • ≥1 week of elevated or irritable mood & increased energy/activity
  • ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if mood is irritable only) (DIGFAST mnemonic):
    • Distractibility
    • Impulsivity/indiscretion, risky behavior
    • Grandiosity
    • Flight of ideas/racing thoughts
    • Increased activity/psychomotor agitation
    • Decreased need for sleep
    • Talkativeness/pressured speech

Severity

  • Impaired psychosocial function
  • May have psychotic features (hallucinations, delusions)
  • May require hospitalization

This patient's 4-week episode of irritability, talkativeness, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, and excessive involvement in new and risky projects is resulting in both relational and occupational impairment and is suggestive of a manic episode of bipolar I disorder.  In manic episodes of bipolar I disorder, the predominant mood may be irritability rather than euphoria. This patient's difficulty sitting still and hyperactivity during the interview are also characteristic.  History of a major depressive episode is not required for diagnosis of bipolar I disorder, although most patients will later have multiple manic and depressive episodes.

Bipolar disorder and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can be difficult to differentiate due to overlapping symptoms (eg, distractibility, hyperactivity, impulsivity), and the conditions can be comorbid.  However, ADHD has a chronic (not episodic) course and presents with ongoing difficulties that begin in childhood.  It would not explain this patient's abrupt change in behavior compared to his baseline 4 weeks ago (Choice B).  More prominent mood symptoms and, in some cases, psychotic symptoms are other features that distinguish bipolar disorder from ADHD.

(Choice A)  Adjustment disorder is diagnosed when symptoms occur in direct response to an identified psychosocial stressor and cannot be explained by another disorder.  Although this patient's symptoms began shortly after a stressful business trip, his behavior is consistent with a manic episode of bipolar disorder.

(Choice D)  Although patients with generalized anxiety disorder may experience irritable mood, poor sleep, and difficulty concentrating, this patient does not display other key features (eg, ≥6 month of uncontrollable concern about multiple daily issues).

(Choice E)  Although cocaine and other drugs with stimulant properties can cause manic symptoms, this patient has not used any illicit drugs other than marijuana for 3 years.  Marijuana use can result in irritability and anxiety, but it would not cause the other symptoms of mania evident in this patient (eg, hyperactivity, decreased need for sleep, increased goal-directed activity, pressured speech).

Educational objective:
Patients with bipolar disorder may exhibit distractibility and hyperactivity that are difficult to distinguish from symptoms of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.  An episodic (not chronic) course and prominent mood symptoms are more characteristic of bipolar disorder.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bipolar disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Bipolar disorder and ADHD: comorbidity and diagnostic distinctions.
Adult ADHD vs. bipolar disorder in the DSM-5 era: a challenging differentiation for clinicians.

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man is admitted to a rehabilitation unit following a stroke that resulted in right-sided weakness and facial droop.  Medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and prostate cancer in remission.  Prior to the stroke, the patient had retired to care for his wife, who has early-onset dementia.  He has shown little effort over the past 3 weeks and has recently refused rehabilitation services, saying, "What's the point?"  The patient's son, who comes to visit a few times a week, says, "Ever since last month's stroke, he seems so resigned and barely talks when I visit.  He seems uninterested in hearing about the grandchildren he adores and has asked his friends not to visit."  The patient says he has had low energy, decreased concentration, and difficulty sleeping since the stroke.  He says, "Of course I feel sad, with all my medical problems and my wife's condition.  I don't know how someone wouldn't feel this way."  He has no suicidal ideation.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's sad and hopeless mood, anhedonia (eg, no interest in family and friends), low energy, impaired concentration, and sleep difficulty meet the criteria for major depressive disorder.  Poststroke depression occurs in nearly one-third of stroke survivors.  However, it is often overlooked in patients recovering from a stroke, contributing to reduced quality of life, decreased adherence to treatment, poorer functional outcomes, and increased mortality.

Early treatment of poststroke depression with antidepressants (eg, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) and/or psychotherapy can alleviate depressive symptoms and enhance physical and cognitive recovery.  Therefore, treatment should be offered without delay (Choice D).  Patients recovering from a stroke and its complications experience wide-ranging and difficult emotions.  Thoughtfully initiating the topic of depression treatment should include empathically validating a patient's experience (eg, "experiencing depression after a stroke is common") followed by education about treatment options (eg, "there are treatments that can help").

(Choice B)  Normalizing the patient's experience is important; however, untreated poststroke depression can have a profound negative impact on stroke recovery, future functioning, and quality of life.  Attributing this patient's condition to a normal grief reaction underestimates the severity of his major depressive disorder and potentially deprives him of effective antidepressant pharmacotherapy and/or psychotherapy intervention.

(Choice C)  Behavioral activation benefits mood, and physical therapy will be necessary to improve strength; however, physical activity alone is not expected to manage this patient's poststroke depressive symptoms and should not be offered in place of first-line effective interventions (eg, antidepressants, psychotherapy).

(Choice E)  Attending a support group may be a useful adjunct to antidepressant treatment and can help patients feel supported in recovery.  However, support groups are not sufficient substitutes for first-line treatment options of major depressive disorders.

Educational objective:
Poststroke depression is common, underdiagnosed, and associated with increased morbidity and mortality.  Patients benefit from empathic validation of their symptoms followed by education about treatment options.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Physician patient communication

answerChoiceList.choice: "Experiencing depression after a stroke is common and can make recovery even more difficult; there are treatments that can help."
"Most people in your situation would feel the same way; your sadness is part of a normal grief reaction to your new physical limitations."
"Physical activity can have a positive effect on mood; participating in rehabilitation can improve your strength and your outlook."
"Your recovery has been difficult given everything that has happened, but you will feel better as you heal emotionally and physically."
"You're trying to process a lot of major life changes; joining a support group can help you connect with other stroke survivors."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Major depressive disorder
Post-stroke depression: a review.
Post-stroke depression: an update.

questionList.questionText: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to restlessness and altered mental status.  His wife reports that the patient awakened at 6:00 AM agitated and slightly confused.  Over the past 2 hours, his symptoms have worsened.  She states that he was well the previous day but went to his primary care doctor due to a persistent, dry cough for 3 weeks following an upper respiratory tract infection.  The patient was prescribed dextromethorphan and an albuterol inhaler.  He has a history of major depressive disorder that is well controlled with fluoxetine.  Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 22/min.  Pulse oximetry is 100% on room air.  The patient is agitated and confused.  Pupils are dilated, and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Hyperreflexia and ankle clonus are noted on neurological examination.  Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Serotonin toxicity

Causes

  • Serotonergic medications, especially in combination (eg, SSRI/SNRI, TCA, tramadol)
  • Drug interactions: serotonergic medication & MAOI or linezolid
  • Intentional overdose of serotonergic medications
  • Serotonergic substances (eg, MDMA, dextromethorphan, amphetamines)

Clinical
features

  • Mental status changes (eg, anxiety, agitation, delirium)
  • Autonomic dysregulation (eg, diaphoresis, hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, vomiting, diarrhea)
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity (eg, tremor, myoclonus, hyperreflexia)

Management

  • Discontinuation of all serotonergic medications
  • Supportive care, sedation with benzodiazepines
  • Serotonin antagonist (cyproheptadine) if supportive measures fail
  • Immediate sedation, paralysis & tracheal intubation if temperature >41.1 C (106 F)

MAOI = monoamine oxidase inhibitor; SNRI = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor; TCA = tricyclic antidepressant.

This patient taking a selective serotonin inhibitor (SSRI) has altered mental status, autonomic instability (eg, hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, mydriasis), and neuromuscular excitability (eg, hyperreflexia, ankle clonus), a triad concerning for serotonin toxicity.  Although it typically follows an increased SSRI (eg, fluoxetine) dosage, serotonin toxicity can also be precipitated by concomitant use of another serotonergic agent.  This patient recently began taking the antitussive dextromethorphan, which primarily activates sigma opioid receptors to inhibit cough but also has serotonergic activity at the 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTA) 2 receptors.

Management often includes:

  • Discontinuation of all serotonergic medications

  • Management of severe hypertension with short-acting antihypertensives (eg, esmolol)

  • Intravenous hydration, and evaporative and convective cooling (eg, fanning, water mist).  Antipyretics are not used because hyperthermia is due to sustained muscle contraction, not elevations in the hypothalamic temperature set point.

  • Benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam) to improve agitation, decrease muscle contraction (which reduces hyperthermia), and decrease blood pressure and heart rate

In patients who are unresponsive to benzodiazepines and supportive care, cyproheptadine is used to lower the serotonergic activity through antagonism of 5-HT1A and 5-HT2A receptors.  Serotonin toxicity can have a relatively rapid onset and progression; some patients require intubation and sedation (eg, for severe hyperthermia).

(Choice A)  Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, is used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS).  Although NMS can also present with hyperthermia and autonomic dysregulation, severe muscle rigidity is typically a prominent feature; myoclonus and hyperreflexia are less common.

(Choice B)  Haloperidol, an antipsychotic that treats psychosis and agitation, should not be used in serotonin toxicity because its anticholinergic properties prevent the dissipation of body heat, exacerbating hyperthermia.

(Choice C)  Although pneumonia (treated with levofloxacin) can present with fever and altered mental status after upper respiratory tract symptoms, this patient's normal oxygen saturation and clear lungs make pneumonia less likely.  Also, it would be unusual for pneumonia to develop suddenly after 3 weeks of dry cough, and dilated pupils and neuromuscular excitability would not be expected.

(Choice E)  Physostigmine is sometimes used to treat anticholinergic toxicity, which can cause delirium, mydriasis, hyperthermia, and hypertension.  However, hyperreflexia and clonus would be unexpected, and this patient's combination of serotonergic medications makes serotonin toxicity more likely.

Educational objective:
Serotonin toxicity is characterized by mental status changes, autonomic dysregulation, and neuromuscular excitability.  Management includes discontinuation of serotonergic medications, hydration, cooling, and blood pressure control.  Benzodiazepines are used to decrease agitation and muscle contractions.  Cyproheptadine is used to decrease central serotonergic activity.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Serotonin toxicity

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Serotonin syndrome.

questionList.questionText: A 33-year-old man is hospitalized for depression with psychotic features.  The patient had been on outpatient phenelzine therapy for major depressive disorder but stopped taking the medication 3 weeks ago because he did not feel that it was helping.  Two days ago, he was brought to the emergency department due to worsening depressive symptoms and new auditory hallucinations.  He was started on citalopram and risperidone and admitted to the inpatient psychiatric unit.  He has not been receiving any other medications.  This morning, he was found to have acute-onset confusion and high fever.  Temperature is 39.4 C (102.9 F), blood pressure is 160/80 mm Hg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 16/min.  On examination, the patient is disoriented and unable to attend to the interview.  He has severe muscle stiffness but no hyperreflexia.  The remainder of the examination is within normal limits.  Laboratory tests are ordered, but results are not yet available.  Which of the following is the most likely provisional diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Signs/symptoms

  • Fever (>40 C [104 F] common)
  • Confusion
  • Muscle rigidity (generalized)
  • Autonomic instability (eg, abnormal vital signs, sweating)

Treatment

  • Stop antipsychotics or restart dopamine agents
  • Supportive care (eg, hydration, cooling), intensive care unit
  • Dantrolene or bromocriptine if refractory

This patient's development of confusion, fever, and severe rigidity in the setting of recent initiation of the antipsychotic risperidone is suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS).  NMS is characterized by autonomic instability (with notably high fevers), delirium, generalized rigidity (often severe), rhabdomyolysis (with increased serum creatine kinase), and leukocytosis.  It is a potentially life-threatening medical condition that can occur any time after treatment with an antipsychotic.  Although most often seen with high-potency first-generation antipsychotics (eg, haloperidol), the syndrome can occur with all antipsychotics.  It can develop over 1-3 days, with delirium often being the first manifestation.

Serotonin syndrome (SS) can be difficult to distinguish from NMS.  SS is characterized by neuromuscular hyperactivity (eg, tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus), rather than the severe, generalized rigidity seen in this patient (Choice E).  SS is typically due to a combination of serotonergic medications or the interaction of serotonergic medications (eg, citalopram) and monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) (eg, switching from an MAOI to an SSRI with less than the required 2-week washout period).  This patient had an adequate washout period given that he stopped the MAOI phenelzine 3 weeks ago before starting citalopram.

(Choice A)  Although malignant catatonia may share some features of NMS, it has an insidious onset and usually presents with a prodrome of motor agitation.  NMS is more likely given the rapid onset of symptoms following initiation of an antipsychotic.

(Choice B)  Malignant hyperthermia may occur in genetically susceptible patients, leading to hypercarbia, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia in the setting of perioperative exposure to volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine.  Onset of malignant hyperthermia is much more rapid than that of NMS.

(Choice C)  Abrupt discontinuation of any antidepressant may result in both medical and neurological symptoms.  However, if present, symptoms occur in the first few days after discontinuation and often subside after 2-3 weeks.

Educational objective:
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening condition associated with the use of antipsychotics.  It is characterized by delirium, high fever, autonomic instability, severe rigidity, elevated creatine kinase, and leukocytosis.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: a review from a clinically oriented perspective.

questionList.questionText: A 58-year-old woman comes to the office due to depressed mood and hopelessness for the past 2 months.  She has no interest in her hobbies or exercising and feels emotionally detached from her family and friends.  The patient awakens every night at 2 AM and is up for the day at 4 AM.  Her appetite is poor, and her children and husband have to remind her to eat.  Her symptoms have caused her to take a leave of absence from work, and she has difficulty sustaining her attention to read a book or follow a television program.  She has no suicidal thoughts.  The patient has a history of depression beginning at age 22 and has had 5 lifetime episodes of major depression with one psychiatric hospitalization following a suicide attempt at age 32.  She has not been hospitalized since then.  Previous treatments have included paroxetine, escitalopram, and venlafaxine.  She is not on any medication currently.  Major depressive disorder is diagnosed, and the patient is started on venlafaxine as she recalls having an excellent response to this medication in the past.  At her 2-week follow-up, she is showing signs of improvement.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment plan for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Major depressive disorder is a highly recurrent illness for most patients.  Due to the high risk of recurrence, patients with ≥2 episodes are candidates for maintenance antidepressant treatment (ie, continuing antidepressants beyond the continuation phase of ~6 months following remission).  Other indications for maintenance therapy (due to high risk of recurrence) include early age of onset (≤18), persistent residual depressive symptoms, and comorbid psychiatric disorders.  Maintenance therapy can be continued for ~1-3 years.

However, patients with a history of highly recurrent illness (eg, ≥3 lifetime depressive episodes), chronic episodes (≥2 years), severe ongoing psychosocial stressors, or severe episodes (eg, suicide attempts) are candidates for maintaining antidepressant treatment indefinitely.

This patient's highly recurrent and severe episodes (ie, 5 previous major depressive episodes and a suicide attempt) make her an appropriate candidate for maintaining antidepressant pharmacotherapy indefinitely.  Recurrent major depression may be conceptualized as a chronic illness similar to other chronic medical diseases (eg, hypertension, diabetes) that often require long-term medications.

(Choice A)  The dose that achieves remission should be maintained.  Reducing the dose had been associated with an increased risk of recurrence.

(Choices B, C, and D)  Given the highly recurrent nature of this patient's illness, maintenance pharmacotherapy is indicated.  If the decision is made to discontinue medication, a gradual taper over several weeks to months is preferable.  Patients with a history of recurrent episodes who discontinue antidepressants should be monitored closely, and antidepressant therapy should be reinstituted at the first signs of recurrence.

Educational objective:
Major depressive disorder is often a recurrent illness.  Patients with ≥3 lifetime depressive episodes, severe episodes (eg, suicide attempts), or episodes lasting ≥2 years are candidates for lifelong antidepressant treatment.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Depression

answerChoiceList.choice: Continue venlafaxine for 1 year, then maintain at a reduced dose
Continue venlafaxine for 1 year, then taper gradually
Continue venlafaxine for 6 months after symptom remission, then taper gradually
Continue venlafaxine for 6 weeks, then discontinue

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents after he was caught shoplifting from an art supply store.  The patient's father says, "For the past 2 weeks, my son has been impossible to manage.  He has become loud, obnoxious, and rude.  He skips doing household chores and stays up all night drawing in his room."  The boy's mother received a phone call from his school last week after he told his teacher that she was "incompetent" and that he intended to drop out.  The patient tells the physician that he lives in "the most boring place in the world" and that his parents are jealous that he is "making a masterpiece that will be famous."  He has a history of a specific learning disorder with impairment in reading.  Family history is significant for depression in a cousin and alcohol abuse in a paternal aunt.  On mental status examination, the patient is easily distracted and struggles to sit still.  He speaks quickly and becomes irritable when the physician attempts to clarify what he is saying.  Routine laboratory tests are within normal range, and urine drug screen is negative.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's behavior?
questionList.explanationText:
Manic episode

Clinical
features

  • ≥1 week of elevated or irritable mood & increased energy/activity
  • ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if mood is irritable only) (DIGFAST mnemonic):
    • Distractibility
    • Impulsivity/indiscretion, risky behavior
    • Grandiosity
    • Flight of ideas/racing thoughts
    • Increased activity/psychomotor agitation
    • Decreased need for sleep
    • Talkativeness/pressured speech

Severity

  • Impaired psychosocial function
  • May have psychotic features (hallucinations, delusions)
  • May require hospitalization

This patient's presentation meets criteria for a manic episode, given the abrupt change in behavior accompanied by a decreased need for sleep, goal-directed activity, grandiosity, and risky behavior (shoplifting), all lasting for a 2-week period.  Difficulty sitting still, distractibility, and rapid, loud speech are also characteristic.  To diagnose bipolar disorder, a single manic episode is required, although most patients will go on to have multiple lifetime manic and depressive episodes.

Adolescents may exhibit mood changes and defiance as they test authority figures in the pursuit of autonomy.  They may also have an unrealistic sense of their abilities and a willingness to engage in risky behavior without a full appreciation of the consequences.  However, a decreased need for sleep, distractibility, and goal-directed activity that represents a distinct change from the patient's baseline should raise suspicion for mania and not be dismissed as normal adolescent behavior (Choice E).  Untreated bipolar disorder impacts psychosocial development and academic achievement and increases the risk for substance use, suicide, psychosis, and legal difficulties.

(Choice A)  Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder can also present with distractibility, hyperactivity, impulsivity, and talkativeness.  However, symptoms are chronic, lasting ≥6 months, with some symptoms presenting prior to age 12.  In comparison, manic episodes are distinct occurrences, as in this case where the patient has experienced abrupt changes in behavior over a 2-week period.

(Choices C and F)  Oppositional defiant disorder presents with an irritable or angry mood, argumentativeness or deliberately annoying behavior, and vindictiveness.  Conduct disorder is more severe, where the rights of others or societal norms are purposefully violated (eg, stealing, destroying property, assaulting others).  Neither would explain an abrupt change in behavior, decreased need for sleep, and increased goal-directed activity.

(Choice D)  Patients with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder have temper outbursts that are out of proportion to the stimulus and inconsistent with developmental age.  Symptoms manifest prior to age 10.

Educational objective:
Mania in adolescence may be confused with normal adolescent moodiness, defiance, overconfidence, and risk taking.  However, an abrupt change from baseline, together with decreased need for sleep, distractibility, excessive goal-directed activity, and grandiosity, should raise suspicion for a manic episode.

questionList.questionText: A 37-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up visit.  One month ago, he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and was started on metformin.  Blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, fasting glucose is 122 mg/dL, and BMI is 29.1 kg/m2.  The patient looks rather dejected and admits that it has been difficult to come to terms with his diagnosis.  He has tried to exercise, watch his oral intake, and quit smoking as was suggested, but lately he has felt unmotivated and without energy.  The patient admits to feeling sad and guilty about his weight and smoking but is not sure he can do anything about it.  He has been oversleeping and then spending much of the day in bed watching television or sleeping due to lack of energy.  He has withdrawn from friends and family and took the last 2 weeks off from work because he did not "feel up to going."  The patient's ability to concentrate and pay attention to daily tasks is significantly impaired.  Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is suffering from a major depressive episode characterized by >2 weeks of depressed mood, anhedonia, sleep disturbance, guilt, and impaired energy, motivation and concentration.  Because no antidepressant has demonstrated superior efficacy, choice of medication is often based on other factors such as side effect profile and medical and psychiatric comorbidity.  Bupropion, a norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor, is a preferred option as it is a first-line antidepressant with a favorable side effect profile for this patient.  It has mild stimulant effects and therefore can increase wakefulness, energy, and concentration.  Bupropion is an approved treatment for smoking cessation and can also help with weight loss.  It does not cause sexual side effects.  Bupropion is contraindicated in patients with a history of seizures and those with eating disorders.

(Choice A)  Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, is sedating and is not considered a first-line antidepressant due to its side effect profile (eg, cardiotoxicity, danger in overdose).

(Choices B and D)  Atomoxetine, a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, and methylphenidate, a stimulant, are used to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.  This patient's impaired attention and concentration are symptoms of his depression.

(Choice E)  Mirtazapine, an antidepressant with serotonergic and noradrenergic activity, can be sedating and increase appetite.

(Choice F)  Modafinil is a wakefulness-promoting agent approved to treat narcolepsy.  It has been used as an adjunct to improve motivation and energy in some patients with psychiatric illness.  It is not an antidepressant and therefore not appropriate in this patient.

(Choice G)  Phenelzine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI), can cause weight gain and is not a first-line medication due to its dietary restrictions and potential for severe side effects (eg, hypertensive crisis, serotonin syndrome).  Although MAOIs have been used to treat atypical depression (hyperphagia, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, and rejection sensitivity), they are reserved for treatment-resistant cases.

Educational objective:
Bupropion is an antidepressant with mild stimulant properties that can be particularly helpful for depressed patients with low energy, impaired concentration, hypersomnia, and weight gain.  It can also be used to aid smoking cessation.

questionList.questionText: A 44-year-old man comes to the office due to depression, loss of interest, impaired concentration, fatigue, and poor sleep.  The patient is not suicidal and has no psychotic symptoms.  He has no psychiatric history.  Physical examination and laboratory evaluation are unremarkable.  Major depressive disorder is diagnosed, and he is treated with 50 mg of sertraline.  After a month of antidepressant treatment, the patient reports improvement in his energy level and sleep, although he continues to struggle with some sadness and low motivation.  The dose of sertraline is increased to 100 mg.  At his 2-month follow-up, the patient has no depressive symptoms and says, "I feel like I'm totally back to normal.  Work is going well and I'm really enjoying life again."  He has no adverse effects from the sertraline.  The patient asks when he can stop taking the medication.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has achieved remission after acute-phase treatment with sertraline.  To decrease the risk of depressive relapse, multiple evidence-based treatment guidelines recommend continuing antidepressant treatment for an additional 6 months in patients with remitted single-episode, unipolar major depression (referred to as continuation-phase treatment).  The dose should be maintained at the level at which remission was achieved and should not be reduced (ie, the dose that gets the patient well keeps the patient well) (Choice A).  If complete remission is maintained at the end of the continuation phase, the antidepressant can then be tapered gradually and discontinued.

Maintenance-phase treatment is defined as continuing antidepressant medication past the initial continuation-phase treatment.  Maintenance for 1-3 years is appropriate for patients with a high risk of recurrence (eg, ≥2 episodes, persistent residual depressive symptoms) (Choice B).  Patients with a history of highly recurrent major depressive disorder (≥3 lifetime depressive episodes), chronic episodes (≥2 years), strong family history, or severe episodes (eg, suicide attempt) should continue maintenance treatment indefinitely (Choice E).

(Choices D and F)  Tapering and discontinuing sertraline now or in 6 weeks would increase the patient's risk for relapse.  Sertraline should be maintained for an additional 6 months to achieve sustained remission.

Educational objective:
Patients with a single episode of major depressive disorder should continue antidepressants for an additional 6 months following acute response to reduce the risk of relapse.  Patients with recurrent, chronic, or severe episodes should be considered for maintenance treatment (1-3 years or indefinitely).

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office due to behavioral difficulties at school.  His grandmother says, "This past year has not been easy for him, but he's been hitting other kids and breaking their toys."  The patient was adopted by his grandmother a year ago after his parents died in a motor vehicle collision.  He attends the same school but no longer wants to play with his friends or join group activities.  The patient wakes up a few times a week, crying about monsters and asking to sleep in his grandmother's room.  He can ride a bike and draw complex shapes.  Vital signs are within normal limits, and he is tracking adequately on growth curves.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  The patient is restless and rams a toy truck into a stuffed animal repeatedly while his grandmother speaks.  He makes poor eye contact and answers most questions by saying "I don't know" despite his grandmother's encouragement.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This child's recurrent nightmares, violent themes in play, emotional reactivity with aggressive play (eg, hitting, breaking), and social withdrawal after a traumatic loss are suggestive of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).  Exposure to trauma can occur through direct involvement in or witnessing of a traumatic event or by learning about violent trauma to a loved one.  Young children with PTSD, whose memories may not be fully consolidated, often have nightmares that are not specific to the traumatic event (eg, monsters, being chased), as well as repetitive traumatic themes in play.  They often struggle with emotional regulation and may appear easily upset or angered with little provocation.  They may struggle with feelings of guilt, shame, or sadness.

Other manifestations include dissociation (which may be mistaken for not paying attention); avoidance of places, people, or discussions related to traumatic incidences; difficulty concentrating; decreased interest in play; and social withdrawal, as seen in this patient.

(Choice A)  Social withdrawal and repetitive acts of aggression toward peers are not typical behaviors for a 5-year-old and warrant further evaluation.

(Choice B)  Difficulty with emotional regulation and resultant impulsivity are often seen in childhood PTSD and may be mistaken for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).  However, this patient lacks evidence of the pervasive inattention and hyperactivity required for the diagnosis of ADHD, and this diagnosis alone would not explain his nightmares, social withdrawal, and aggressive themes in play.

(Choice C)  This patient lacks the restricted interests and stereotypical behaviors typically seen in autism spectrum disorder.  His poor eye contact and reluctance to engage with the physician are more likely due to avoidance of discussing distressing topics rather than the deficits in social communication characteristic of this disorder.

(Choice D)  Oppositional defiant disorder presents with an irritable mood accompanied by vindictiveness and defiance of rules, which is deliberate in nature rather than a result of emotional distress.  It would not explain repeated nightmares and traumatic themes in play.

(Choice F)  Reactive attachment disorder is an extreme outcome of early childhood abuse, which results in a lack of emotional responsiveness and the absence of comfort-seeking from caregivers.

Educational objective:
Posttraumatic stress disorder in children may present with distressing dreams with vague content and reenactment of traumatic themes in play, rather than clearly formulated memories.  This is often accompanied by emotional dysregulation and behavioral difficulties.

questionList.questionText: A 38-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and obesity comes to the office for a routine follow-up visit.  Three months ago, the patient was diagnosed with a major depressive episode, characterized by a month of persistently depressed mood, isolative behaviors, staying in bed all day, low energy, poor concentration, and low libido.  She was started on escitalopram, and a low dose of bupropion was added 6 weeks later to help with energy and concentration.  She no longer feels depressed but is distressed that her libido remains low and her sexual arousal has decreased further.  The patient does not use alcohol or recreational drugs.  Other medications include metformin and enalapril, which she takes regularly.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 68/min.  Examination shows no new abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's current sexual dysfunction?
questionList.explanationText:
SSRI- & SNRI-associated sexual dysfunction

Features

  • Decreased libido
  • Anorgasmia
  • Delayed ejaculation
  • Common cause of nonadherence

Assessment & management

  • Rule out sexual dysfunction due to depression, medical conditions, primary sexual disorder, stress/relationship issues, substance abuse
  • Switch to non-SSRI or non-SNRI antidepressant: Bupropion or mirtazapine
  • Adjunctive therapy with sildenafil or bupropion
  • Dose reduction for patients on high-dose SSRI (monitor for loss of efficacy)

SNRI = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

The patient is most likely experiencing SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction secondary to treatment with escitalopram.  Both selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) can cause sexual side effects.  In women, these effects may include decreased sexual interest and arousal if mild or moderate, or anorgasmia if severe.  In men, decreased libido, and in more severe cases erectile dysfunction and inability to ejaculate, may occur.

Psychological factors, substance use, and medical conditions such as vascular, hormonal, and neurological disorders may also cause sexual dysfunction.  However, despite the presence of baseline obesity, diabetes, and hypertension in this patient, these conditions are stable and less likely to be responsible for the recent onset of her worsening sexual dysfunction (Choices C, F, and G).

(Choice A)  Bupropion does not cause sexual dysfunction and is often tried as adjunctive therapy to manage SSRI-related sexual dysfunction.

(Choice B)  Depression-related sexual dysfunction would be expected to improve along with the patient's other depressive symptoms and therefore would not explain her worsening symptoms.

(Choice E)  Female sexual interest/arousal disorder is characterized by significant impairment in sexual arousal and interest lasting 6 months or longer; it is unrelated to substances, medications, or other medical etiologies.

Educational objective:
Serotonergic antidepressants such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) can cause sexual dysfunction in both women and men.  Psychiatric and other medical conditions can also cause sexual dysfunction.  However, the temporal association of the symptoms (or their worsening) to SSRI/SNRI antidepressant use often indicates a medication-related cause.
